Detection	O
of	O
mutations	O
of	O
p53	B-GENE
tumor	O

in	O

K-ras	B-GENE

.	O

,	O
Watanabe	O

of	O
Internal	O

Because	O
of	O
the	O
difficulty	O
in	O
obtaining	O
biopsy	O
specimens	O
from	O
pancreatic	O
cancer	O
patients	O
,	O
K-ras	B-GENE
mutation	O
analysis	O
in	O
pancreatic	O
juice	O
has	O
been	O
used	O
for	O
specific	O
diagnosis	O
.	O
But	O
recently	O
,	O
false	O
positives	O
have	O
been	O
obtained	O
with	O
this	O
method	O
.	O
To	O
improve	O
the	O
genetic	O
diagnosis	O
of	O
pancreatic	O
cancer	O
,	O
detection	O
of	O
p53	B-GENE
gene	O
mutation	O
in	O
pancreatic	O
juice	O
was	O
studied	O
.	O
Pancreatic	O
juice	O
was	O
sampled	O
endoscopically	O
.	O
Single	O
-	O
strand	O
conformation	O
polymorphism	O
analysis	O
was	O
used	O
for	O
p53	B-GENE
mutation	O
analysis	O
.	O
Furthermore	O
,	O
K-ras	B-GENE
mutations	O
at	O
codon	O
12	O
were	O
also	O
studied	O
in	O
the	O
same	O
pancreatic	O
cancer	O
patients	O
.	O
Of	O
26	O
cases	O
of	O
pancreatic	O
cancer	O
,	O
p53	B-GENE
mutations	O
were	O
detected	O
in	O
11	O
(	O
42.3	O
%	O
)	O
.	O
No	O
mutations	O
were	O
seen	O
in	O
the	O
cases	O
with	O
mucin	B-GENE
-	O
producing	O
adenoma	O
nor	O
with	O
chronic	O
pancreatitis	O
.	O
K-ras	B-GENE
mutations	O
were	O
detected	O
in	O
84.0	O
%	O
of	O
cases	O
by	O
RFLP	O
analysis	O
,	O
which	O
has	O
high	O
sensitivity	O
,	O
and	O
in	O
65.3	O
%	O
by	O
hybridization	O
protection	O
assay	O
,	O
which	O
has	O
high	O
specificity	O
.	O
Using	O
a	O
combination	O
assay	O
with	O
both	O
genes	O
,	O
genetic	O
abnormalities	O
were	O
detected	O
in	O
92.0	O
%	O
by	O
RFLP	O
and	O
73	O
.1	O
%	O
by	O
hybridization	O
protection	O
assay	O
including	O
two	O
cases	O
in	O
which	O
p53	B-GENE
alone	O
was	O
positive	O
by	O
both	O
methods	O
.	O
The	O
specificity	O
of	O
p53	B-GENE
mutation	O
for	O
pancreatic	O
cancer	O
is	O
very	O
high	O
.	O
Therefore	O
,	O
simultaneous	O
analysis	O
of	O
p53	B-GENE
and	O
K-ras	B-GENE
mutation	O
is	O
suggested	O
to	O
enhance	O
the	O
genetic	O

of	O
pancreatic	O
cancer	O

Association	O
of	O
K-ras	B-GENE
mutations	O
with	O
p16	B-GENE
methylation	O
in	O
human	O
colon	O
cancer	O
.	O
Guan	O
RJ	O
,	O
Fu	O
Y	O
,	O
Holt	O
PR	O
,	O
Pardee	O
AB	O
.	O
Division	O
of	O
Gastroenterology	O
,	O
Brigham	O
&	O
Women	O
's	O
Hospital	O
,	O
Boston	O
,	O
USA	O
.	O
rguan@mbcrr	O
.harvard	O
.edu	O
BACKGROUND	O
&	O
AIMS	O
:	O
K-ras	B-GENE
mutations	O
are	O
early	O
genetic	O
changes	O
in	O
colon	O
cancer	O
.	O
p16	B-GENE
,	O
a	O
tumor	O
-	O
suppressor	O
gene	O
,	O
is	O
inactivated	O
in	O
neoplasms	O
by	O
mutation	O
,	O
deletion	O
,	O
or	O
methylation	O
.	O
The	O
aims	O
of	O
this	O
study	O
were	O
to	O
determine	O
p16	B-GENE
methylation	O
status	O
and	O
its	O
possible	O
association	O
with	O
K-ras	B-GENE
mutations	O
in	O
human	O
colon	O
cancer	O
.	O
METHODS	O
:	O
DNA	O
isolated	O
from	O
8	O
colon	O
cancer	O
cell	O
lines	O
and	O
41	O
microdissected	O
human	O
colon	O
tissue	O
samples	O
was	O
analyzed	O
.	O
p16	B-GENE
methylation	O
status	O
was	O
determined	O
using	O
two	O
analytical	O
methods	O
.	O
The	O
level	O
of	O
p16	B-GENE
expression	O
was	O
determined	O
by	O
reverse	O
-	O
transcription	O
polymerase	B-GENE
chain	O
reaction	O
and	O
Northern	O
blot	O
.	O
K-ras	B-GENE
mutations	O
were	O
determined	O
by	O
DNA	O
sequence	O
analysis	O
.	O
The	O
DNA	O
methyltransferase	B-GENE
activity	O
was	O
determined	O
by	O
microassay	O
.	O
Parental	O
and	O
K-ras	B-GENE
-	O
transformed	O
IEC-18	O
cells	O
were	O
used	O
to	O
determine	O
the	O
potential	O
association	O
between	O
K-ras	B-GENE
mutations	O
and	O
p16	B-GENE
methylation	O
.	O
RESULTS	O
:	O
Methylated	O
p16	B-GENE
was	O
found	O
in	O
100	O
%	O
of	O
colon	O
cancer	O
cell	O
lines	O
,	O
55	O
%	O
of	O
colon	O
cancers	O
,	O
54	O
%	O
of	O
adenomas	O
,	O
and	O
25	O
%	O
of	O
transitional	O
mucosa	O
but	O
not	O
in	O
normal	O
colonic	O
epithelium	O
.	O
Forty	O
-five	O
percent	O
of	O
cancers	O
and	O
38	O
%	O
of	O
adenomas	O
showed	O
both	O
K-ras	B-GENE
mutations	O
and	O
p16	B-GENE
methylation	O
.	O
Of	O
11	O
cancers	O
and	O
adenomas	O
with	O
K-ras	B-GENE
mutation	O
,	O
10	O
specimens	O
showed	O
methylated	O
p16	B-GENE
.	O
In	O
contrast	O
,	O
of	O
13	O
adenomas	O
and	O
cancers	O
with	O
wild-type	O
K-ras	B-GENE
,	O
only	O
3	O
specimens	O
showed	O
methylated	O
p16	O
(	O
P	O
=	O
0.001	O
)	O
.	O
Stable	O
transformation	O
of	O
IEC-18	O
cells	O
with	O
K-ras	B-GENE
increased	O
the	O
DNA	O
methyltransferase	B-GENE
activity	O
,	O
methylated	O
the	O
p16	B-GENE
gene	O
,	O
and	O
suppressed	O
the	O
expression	O
of	O
p16	B-GENE
.	O
Treatment	O
with	O
a	O
DNA	O
methylation	O
inhibitor	O
(	O
azadeoxycytidine	O
)	O
resulted	O
in	O
reexpression	O
of	O
p16	B-GENE
in	O
K-ras	B-GENE
-	O
transformed	O
IEC-18	O
cells	O
,	O
suggesting	O
that	O
the	O
expression	O
of	O
p16	B-GENE
was	O
suppressed	O
by	O
DNA	O
methylation	O
.	O
CONCLUSIONS	O
:	O
p16	B-GENE
methylation	O
occurs	O
frequently	O
in	O
human	O
colonic	O
adenomas	O
and	O
cancers	O
and	O
is	O
closely	O
associated	O
with	O
K-ras	B-GENE
mutations	O
.	O

:	O

Frequent	O
mutation	O
and	O
nuclear	O
localization	O
of	O
beta-catenin	B-GENE
in	O
anaplastic	O
thyroid	O
carcinoma	O
.	O
Garcia-Rostan	O
G	O
,	O
Tallini	O
G	O
,	O
Herrero	O

,	O
D'Aquila	O

of	O

06520	O

Beta-catenin	B-GENE
is	O
an	O
ubiquitously	O
expressed	O
cytoplasmic	O
protein	O
that	O
has	O
a	O
crucial	O
role	O
in	O
both	O
E-cadherin	B-GENE
-	O
mediated	O
cell	O
-	O
cell	O
adhesion	O
and	O
as	O
a	O
downstream	O
signaling	O
molecule	O
in	O
the	O
wingless	B-GENE
pathway	O
.	O
Stabilization	O
of	O
beta-catenin	B-GENE
followed	O
by	O
nuclear	O
translocation	O
and	O
subsequent	O
T-cell	B-GENE
factor	I-GENE
/	O
lymphoid	B-GENE
-	I-GENE
enhancing	I-GENE
factor	I-GENE
-	O
mediated	O
transcriptional	O
activation	O
has	O
been	O
proposed	O
as	O
an	O
important	O
step	O
in	O
oncogenesis	O
.	O
Stabilization	O
may	O
occur	O
through	O
activating	O
mutations	O
in	O
exon-3	O
at	O
the	O
phosphorylation	O
sites	O
for	O
ubiquitination	O
and	O
degradation	O
of	O
beta-catenin	B-GENE
.	O
Immunohistochemical	O
subcellular	O
localization	O
of	O
beta-catenin	B-GENE
and	O
mutational	O
analysis	O
of	O
exon-3	O
of	O
the	O
beta-catenin	B-GENE
gene	O
by	O
single	O
-	O
strand	O
conformational	O
polymorphism	O
followed	O
by	O
DNA	O
sequencing	O
was	O
performed	O
on	O
37	O
samples	O
from	O
31	O
patients	O
with	O
anaplastic	O
thyroid	O
carcinoma	O
.	O
Immunofluorescent	O
staining	O
showed	O
nuclear	O
localization	O
in	O
15	O
(	O
42	O
%	O
)	O
of	O
the	O
36	O
samples	O
examined	O
.	O
Nucleotide	O
sequencing	O
of	O
mobility	O
shifts	O
detected	O
by	O
single	O
-	O
strand	O
conformational	O
polymorphism	O
revealed	O
somatic	O
alterations	O
in	O
19	O
(	O
61	O
%	O
)	O
of	O
the	O
31	O
patients	O
analyzed	O
.	O
We	O
conclude	O
that	O
mutations	O
in	O
beta-catenin	B-GENE
are	O
common	O
in	O
anaplastic	O
thyroid	O
cancer	O
and	O
that	O
they	O
may	O
activate	O
transcription	O
,	O
as	O
illustrated	O
by	O
frequent	O
nuclear	O
localization	O
of	O
the	O
protein	O
.	O
These	O
findings	O
support	O
the	O
idea	O
that	O
beta-catenin	B-GENE
acts	O
as	O
an	O
oncogene	O
and	O
contributes	O
to	O
the	O
highly	O
aggressive	O
behavior	O
of	O
this	O
tumor	O
.	O

and	O

analysis	O
of	O
giant	O
cell	O
carcinoma	O
of	O
the	O

:	O
a	O
report	O
of	O
three	O
cases	O
.	O
Imai	O

,	O
Morishita	O

,	O

of	O

We	O
performed	O
molecular	O
biological	O
studies	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
immunohistochemical	O
analysis	O
of	O
three	O
cases	O
of	O
giant	O
cell	O

of	O
the	O
pancreas	O
.	O
Histologically	O
,	O
one	O
case	O
was	O
a	O

giant	O

carcinoma	O
consisting	O
of	O
pleomorphic	O
giant	O
/	O

cells	O
and	O

cells	O

one	O
an	O
osteoclast	O
-	O

cell	O

composed	O
of	O
osteoclastoid	O
giant	O
cells	O
and	O
pleomorphic	O
small	O
cells	O

and	O
one	O
a	O
pleomorphic	O
giant	O
cell	O
carcinoma	O
with	O
osteoclastoid	O
giant	O
cells	O
.	O
Immunohistochemically	O
,	O
pleomorphic	O
giant	O
cells	O
and	O
small	O
pleomorphic	O
cells	O
were	O
positive	O
for	O
epithelial	O
and	O
mesenchymal	O
markers	O
throughout	O
the	O
cases	O
.	O
Osteoclastoid	O
cells	O
were	O
strongly	O
positive	O
for	O
PG-M1	B-GENE
(	O
CD68	B-GENE
)	O
,	O
but	O
negative	O
for	O
lysozyme	B-GENE
and	O
epithelial	O
markers	O
.	O
Pleomorphic	O
spindle	O
cells	O
showed	O
the	O
same	O
immunoreactivity	O
as	O
pleomorphic	O
giant	O
/small	O
cells	O
.	O
Genetically	O
,	O
all	O
cases	O
contained	O
a	O
mutation	O
in	O
the	O
K-ras	B-GENE
(	O

,	O
13	O
)	O
oncogene	O
,	O
but	O
neither	O
p53	B-GENE
(	O
exons	O
5-	O
8	O
)	O
nor	O

(	O
exons	O
1	O
,	O
2	O
)	O
gene	O
mutations	O
were	O
found	O
in	O
any	O
case	O
.	O
Furthermore	O
,	O
Loss	O
of	O
heterozygosity	O
(	O
LOH	O
)	O
of	O
the	O
p53	B-GENE
,	O
p161NK4	B-GENE
.	O
APC	B-GENE
,	O
and	O
DPC4	B-GENE
gene	O
loci	O
was	O
not	O
found	O
in	O
any	O
of	O
the	O
cases	O
.	O
Immunohistochemical	O
study	O
demonstrated	O
this	O
tumor	O
to	O
be	O
of	O
epithelial	O
origin	O
with	O
mesenchymal	O
differentiation	O
.	O
Genetically	O

to	O
that	O
of	O
usual	O

but	O

might	O
be	O
rather	O
different	O
.	O

histologic	O
and	O
biologic	O
features	O

this	O
tumor	O
would	O
be	O

in	O
other	O

genes	O
.	O

OBJECTIVE	O
:	O
To	O
evaluate	O
clinical	O
parameters	O
,	O
presurgical	O
diagnostic	O
tests	O
,	O
histologic	O
findings	O
,	O
and	O
the	O
presence	O
of	O
K-ras	B-GENE
oncogene	O
mutations	O
in	O
cystic	O
tumors	O
of	O
the	O
pancreas	O
to	O
determine	O
which	O
best	O
predict	O
malignancy	O
.	O
SUMMARY	O
BACKGROUND	O
DATA	O
:	O
Because	O
presurgical	O
,	O
intraoperative	O
,	O
and	O
final	O
pathologic	O
differentiation	O
is	O
difficult	O
in	O
cystic	O
tumors	O
of	O
the	O
pancreas	O
,	O
it	O
would	O
be	O
a	O
major	O
benefit	O
to	O
identify	O
markers	O
that	O
accurately	O
predict	O
malignancy	O
in	O
these	O
rare	O
tumors	O
.	O
The	O
role	O
of	O
K-ras	B-GENE
oncogene	O
mutations	O
as	O
an	O
indicator	O
of	O
malignancy	O
has	O
not	O
been	O
determined	O
in	O
these	O
tumors	O
.	O
METHODS	O
:	O

(	O

are	O

in	O

are	O

in	O

not	O

with	O

have	O

that	O

(	O
12	O
,	O

and	O
61	O
)	O

are	O

to	O

.	O

PURPOSE	O
:	O
To	O
investigate	O
the	O

status	O
of	O
the	O
Ki-ras	B-GENE
gene	O

evaluate	O
a	O
correlation	O
of	O
the	O
genotype	O
with	O
clinical	O
and	O
histopathologic	O
variables	O
.	O
METHODS	O
:	O
Tumor	O
samples	O
were	O
microdissected	O
from	O
sectioned	O
archival	O
paraffin	O
-	O
embedded	O
tissue	O
.	O
Ki-ras	B-GENE
genomic	O
sequences	O
(	O
exons	O
1	O
and	O
2	O
)	O
were	O
amplified	O
by	O
polymerase	B-GENE
chain	O
reaction	O
then	O
analyzed	O
by	O
single	O
-	O
strand	O
conformation	O
polymorphism	O
and	O
direct	O
sequencing	O
.	O
Tissue	O
sections	O
,	O
flanking	O
the	O
analyzed	O
samples	O

were	O
stained	O
with	O
hematoxylin	O
and	O
eosin	O
for	O
examination	O
by	O
light	O

.	O
RESULTS	O
:	O

of	O
12	O
tumors	O
had	O
mutation	O
in	O
exon	O
1	O
,	O
codon	O
12	O
of	O
the	O
Ki-ras	B-GENE
gene	O
;	O
none	O
had	O
mutation	O
in	O
exon	O
2	O
.	O

intensity	O
of	O
the	O
mutated	O
alleles	O
indicates	O
clonal	O
mutation	O
in	O
the	O
tumor	O
cell	O

.	O
One	O
of	O
four	O

all	O
three	O

a	O

.	O

one	O
of	O
nine	O

to	O
poorly	O
differentiated	O
tumors	O
harbored	O
a	O
mutation	O
.	O
CONCLUSIONS	O
:	O
Ki-ras	B-GENE
,	O
an	O
oncogene	O
seldom	O
altered	O
in	O
neuroectodermal	O
neoplasms	O
,	O
is	O
mutated	O
in	O
one	O
third	O
of	O
the	O
retinoblastomas	O
studied	O
.	O
The	O
Ki-ras	B-GENE
mutations	O
are	O
clonal	O
,	O
suggesting	O
that	O

.	O

activity	O
is	O
found	O
exclusively	O
in	O
the	O
cellular	O
nucleus	O
and	O
is	O
present	O
at	O
a	O
lower	O
level	O
in	O
African	O
green	O
monkey	O
kidney	O
Vero	O
cells	O
.	O
Experiments	O
with	O
mixed	O
cell	O
extracts	O
suggest	O
that	O
the	O
low	O
activity	O
in	O
Vero	O
cells	O
is	O
not	O
due	O
to	O
inhibitory	O
factors	O
.	O
These	O
findings	O
support	O
the	O
hypothesis	O
that	O
this	O
RNA-modifying	O
and	O
-unwinding	O
activity	O
is	O
responsible	O
for	O
biased	O
hypermutation	O
of	O
MV	O
strains	O
that	O
infect	O
the	O
central	O
nervous	O
system	O
.	O
Possible	O
functions	O
of	O
this	O
neural	O
cell	O
activity	O
and	O
implications	O
for	O
central	O
nervous	O
system	O
disorders	O
are	O
discussed	O
.	O

:	O

Insulin-like	B-GENE

of	O

was	O

in	O

,	O

growth	B-GENE

This	O
report	O
describes	O
a	O
retrospective	O
study	O
of	O
23	O
patients	O
with	O
incidentally	O
discovered	O
adrenal	O
masses	O
.	O
Two	O
patients	O
with	O
subclinical	O
cortisol	O
secretion	O
developed	O
adrenal	O
insufficiency	O
after	O
removal	O
of	O
benign	O
adenomas	O
.	O
Another	O
patient	O
,	O
who	O
probably	O
harbors	O
an	O
asymptomatic	O
pheochromocytoma	O

developed	O
a	O

when	O
a	O
mass	O
was	O
palpated	O
during	O
aortic	O
vascular	O
surgery	O
.	O
Twelve	O
patients	O
underwent	O
surgery	O
.	O
Seven	O
benign	O
adenomas	O
,	O
an	O
angiomyolipoma	O
,	O
and	O
a	O
cyst	O
were	O
removed	O
.	O
Three	O
patients	O
had	O
malignant	O
masses	O
that	O
include	O
an	O
angiosarcoma	O
,	O
an	O
adrenal	O
adenocarcinoma	O

and	O
a	O
congenital	O
neuroblastoma	O
.	O
We	O
conclude	O
that	O
hormones	O
,	O
especially	O
cortisol	O
,	O
may	O
be	O
secreted	O
in	O
subclinical	O

by	O
incidentally	O
discovered	O
masses	O
.	O
We	O
recommend	O
a	O
concise	O
laboratory	O
evaluation	O
that	O
includes	O
an	O
overnight	O
dexamethasone	O
suppression	O
test	O
.	O

on	O
our	O
interpretation	O
of	O
the	O
literature	O

we	O
believe	O
masses	O
greater	O
than	O
3	O
cm	O
in	O
size	O
should	O
be	O
removed	O
.	O

who	O
do	O
not	O

surgery	O

have	O
computed	O
tomographic	O
scans	O
repeated	O

year	O
and	O
should	O
be	O
reassessed	O

of	O
hormone	O
secretion	O

NMYC	B-GENE
is	O
a	O

65	O

;	O
166	O
were	O
male	O
and	O
123	O
female	O
.	O
RESULTS	O
:	O

eye	O
inclusions	O
are	O
an	O
uncommon	O
finding	O
and	O
appeared	O
in	O
only	O
13	O

of	O
metastatic	O
adenocarcinoma	O
of	O
the	O

.	O

.	O

Hamada	O
H	O
.	O
We	O
have	O
previously	O
isolated	O
long-range	O
acting	O
enhancer	O
elements	O
from	O
the	O
HeLa	O
genome	O
by	O
functional	O
selection	O
.	O
In	O
this	O
report	O
,	O
the	O
structural	O
and	O
functional	O
characteristics	O
of	O
one	O
(	O
GA1	O
)	O
of	O
the	O
enhancers	O
are	O
reported	O
.	O

cloning	O
various	O
restriction	O
fragments	O
and	O
by	O
deletion	O
mutagenesis	O
,	O
the	O
activity	O
of	O
GA1	O
was	O
located	O
in	O
a	O
230-bp	O
region	O
.	O

sequence	O
of	O

that	O

human	O

(	O

)	O
18	O
DNA	O
that	O
had	O
been	O

into	O
the	O
HeLa	O
genome	O
.	O

enhancer	O
is	O
located	O
in	O
the	O

-	O

region	O
of	O
the	O
HPV	O
18	O
genome	O

of	O

several	O

the	O

repressed	O

products	O
.	O

18	O

shows	O
a	O

:	O
it	O

some	O

Buthionine	O
sulfoximine	O
(	O
BSO	O
)	O
selectively	O
inhibits	O
glutathione	O
(	O

)	O

and	O
has	O
been	O
used	O
to	O

cells	O
to	O

agents	O

but	O
has	O
minimal	O

for	O
most	O
cell	O
types	O
.	O

determined	O
the	O
cytotoxicity	O
of	O
BSO	O
for	O
18	O
(	O
12	O
MYCN	B-GENE
amplified	O
;	O
6	O

nonamplified	O

cell	O

assay	O

was	O

(	O

Perturbation	O
of	O
the	O
function	O
of	O
the	O
retinoblastoma	B-GENE
(	O
Rb	B-GENE
)	O
protein	O
is	O
found	O
in	O
most	O
human	O
tumors	O
.	O
Id2	B-GENE
is	O
a	O
natural	O
target	O
of	O
the	O
Rb	B-GENE
protein	O
that	O
is	O
recruited	O
by	O
Myc	B-GENE
oncoproteins	O
to	O
bypass	O
the	O
tumor	O
suppressor	O
function	O
of	O
Rb	B-GENE
.	O
Here	O
we	O
report	O
that	O
an	O
"	O
N-Myc	B-GENE
-	O
Id2	B-GENE
pathway	O
"	O
persists	O
during	O
late	O
development	O
of	O
the	O
nervous	O
system	O
and	O
parallels	O
the	O
rising	O
levels	O
of	O
active	O
Rb	B-GENE
in	O
neuronal	O
precursors	O
withdrawing	O
from	O
the	O
cell	O
cycle	O
.	O
An	O
immunohistochemical	O
analysis	O
of	O
primary	O
neuroblastoma	O
from	O
47	O
patients	O
shows	O
that	O
expression	O
of	O
Id2	B-GENE
is	O
strongly	O
predictive	O
of	O
poor	O
outcome	O
,	O
irrespective	O
of	O
other	O
clinical	O
and	O
biological	O
variables	O
.	O
Overexpression	O
of	O
Id2	B-GENE
mediates	O
cellular	O
transformation	O
and	O
is	O
required	O
to	O
maintain	O
the	O
malignant	O
behavior	O
of	O
neuroblastoma	O
cells	O
.	O
Correspondingly	O
,	O
embryonic	O
fibroblasts	O
from	O
Id2-	B-GENE
null	O
mice	O
display	O
impaired	O
ability	O
to	O
proliferate	O
.	O
We	O
suggest	O
that	O
Id2	B-GENE
overexpression	O
may	O
be	O
a	O
better	O
prognostic	O
indicator	O
than	O
N-myc	B-GENE
gene	O
amplification	O
in	O
neuroblastoma	O
.	O
Thus	O
,	O
disrupting	O
Id2	B-GENE
function	O
may	O
lead	O
to	O
new	O
and	O
useful	O
therapeutic	O
strategies	O
for	O
cancer	O
patients	O
.	O

Fibroblast	B-GENE

(	O

)	O
is	O
a	O

factor	O

the	O

and	O

of	O
the	O
central	O

expression	O

gene	O
expression	O

free	O
media	O

gene	O

like	I-GENE
growth	I-GENE

II	I-GENE

.	O

expressed	O

.	O

.	O

receptor	I-GENE
are	O

to	O
prevent	O

.	O

cells	O

BACKGROUND.	O
Encouraging	O
results	O
have	O
been	O
reported	O
with	O
high	O
dose	O
chemotherapy	O
and	O
total	O
body	O
radiation	O
followed	O
by	O
bone	O
marrow	O
autotransplantation	O
in	O
children	O
with	O
advanced	O
neuroblastoma	O
;	O
however	O
,	O
relapse	O
remains	O
a	O
significant	O
problem	O
.	O
METHODS	O
.	O
The	O
authors	O
treated	O
22	O
children	O
with	O
advanced	O
neuroblastoma	O
with	O
high	O
dose	O
chemotherapy	O
,	O
surgery	O
,	O
intraoperative	O
radiation	O
,	O
and	O
a	O
bone	O
marrow	O
autotransplant	O
(	O
treated	O
in	O
vitro	O
to	O
remove	O
tumor	O
cells	O
)	O
followed	O
by	O
13-cis	O
-	O
retinoic	O
acid	O
.	O
RESULTS	O
.	O
The	O
3-year	O
relapse	O
rate	O
was	O
25	O
%	O
(	O
95	O
%	O
confidence	O
interval	O
[	O
CI]	O
,	O
6-44	O
%	O
)	O
.	O
The	O
3-year	O
disease	O
free	O
survival	O
rate	O
was	O
72	O
%	O
(	O
95	O
%	O
CI	O
,	O
52-	O
92	O
%	O
)	O
.	O
Toxicities	O
included	O
hemolytic	O
uremic	O
syndrome	O
,	O
herpes	O
infection	O
,	O
and	O
hepatic	O
venoocclusive	O
disease	O
.	O
CONCLUSION	O
.	O
These	O
data	O
suggest	O
that	O
this	O
treatment	O
strategy	O
offers	O
an	O
increased	O
rate	O
of	O
3-year	O
disease	O
free	O
survival	O
.	O
The	O
nonrandomized	O
nature	O
of	O
this	O
study	O
and	O
its	O
use	O
of	O
multiple	O
modalities	O
precludes	O
the	O
analysis	O
of	O
the	O
specific	O
contribution	O
of	O
each	O
treatment	O
component	O
and	O
comparison	O
with	O
conventional	O
therapy	O
.	O

BACKGROUND	O
:	O
Olfactory	O
neuroblastoma	O
(	O
ONB	O
)	O
is	O
an	O
uncommon	O
tumor	O
,	O
presenting	O
as	O
a	O
polypoid	O
mass	O
arising	O
from	O
the	O
upper	O
nasal	O
cavity	O
.	O
This	O
tumor	O
has	O
been	O
seldom	O
diagnosed	O
by	O
direct	O
fine	O
needle	O
aspiration	O
(	O
FNA	O
)	O
.	O
CASE	O
:	O
Metastatic	O
ONB	O
was	O
diagnosed	O
by	O
FNA	O
.	O
The	O
patient	O
was	O
a	O
40	O

year	O
-	O
old	O
female	O
with	O
a	O
polypoid	O

and	O
ipsilateral	O
cervical	O
lymphadenopathy	O
.	O

punch	O

of	O

a	O

small	O
round	O

with	O

consistent	O
with	O
ONB	O
.	O

from	O

node	O

there	O
were	O
well	O
-	O
preserved	O

small	O

with	O
hyperchromatic	O
nuclei	O
,	O

and	O

.	O

were	O
occasional	O

as	O
well	O
as	O
rare	O
true	O
rosettes	O
.	O

were	O

.	O

Cyclin	B-GENE
dependent	I-GENE
kinase	I-GENE
5	I-GENE
(	O
Cdk5	B-GENE
)	O
is	O
a	O
proline	O
-direct	O
protein	O
kinase	B-GENE
that	O
is	O
most	O
active	O
in	O
the	O
CNS	O
,	O
and	O
has	O
been	O
implicated	O
as	O
a	O
contributing	O
factor	O
in	O
certain	O
neurodegenerative	O
diseases	O
.	O
Further	O
,	O
there	O
is	O
evidence	O
to	O
suggest	O
that	O
Cdk5	B-GENE
may	O
facilitate	O
the	O
progression	O
of	O
apoptosis	O
.	O
However	O

the	O
mechanisms	O
involved	O
have	O
not	O
been	O
elucidated	O
.	O
The	O
tumor	O
suppressor	O
protein	O
p53	B-GENE
,	O
a	O
transcription	O
factor	O
that	O
is	O
regulated	O
by	O
phosphorylation	O
,	O
increases	O
the	O
expression	O
of	O
genes	O
that	O
control	O
growth	O
arrest	O
or	O
cell	O
death	O
.	O

understand	O
how	O
Cdk5	B-GENE
could	O
facilitate	O
apoptosis	O

the	O
effects	O
of	O

on	O
p53	B-GENE
activity	O
were	O
examined	O
.	O

present	O
study	O

is	O
shown	O
that	O

apoptotic	O
PC12	O
cells	O

of	O

and	O

.	O

/	O

effectively	O
phosphorylates	O
recombinant	O
p53	B-GENE
in	O
vitro	O
.	O

of	O

p25	B-GENE
into	O
cells	O
results	O
in	O
an	O
increase	O

levels	O

well	O
as	O
the	O
expression	O
of	O
the	O
p53	B-GENE
-	O
responsive	O
genes	O
p21	B-GENE
and	O
Bax	B-GENE
.	O
Furthermore	O
,	O
evidence	O
is	O
provided	O
that	O
increased	O

activity	O
increases	O
p53	B-GENE
transcriptional	O
activity	O
significantly	O

that	O

is	O

BACKGROUND	O
.	O
Amplification	O
of	O
the	O
MYCN	B-GENE
oncogene	O
,	O
formerly	O
known	O
as	O

-	I-GENE

,	O
has	O
been	O
seen	O
in	O
several	O
malignant	O
tumors	O
,	O
particularly	O
neuroblastoma	O
,	O
where	O
its	O
association	O
with	O
a	O
poor	O
clinical	O
outcome	O
is	O
the	O
clearest	O
example	O
of	O
a	O

relevant	O

in	O
any	O
human	O

.	O
METHODS	O
.	O
The	O
incidence	O
and	O
clinical	O

of	O

amplification	O
in	O
rhabdomyosarcoma	O
(	O

)	O

assessed	O
by	O
Southern	O

in	O
this	O

study	O
of	O
seven	O

and	O
six	O

RMS	O
.	O
RESULTS	O
.	O
MYCN	B-GENE
amplification	O
(	O
4	O

to	O
13	O
-	O
fold	O
)	O
was	O
present	O
in	O
three	O
of	O
seven	O

(	O
42.9	O
%	O
)	O
but	O

of	O
the	O

RMS	O
.	O

was	O
no	O

difference	O
between	O
the	O

of	O

MYCN	B-GENE
-	O

and	O

no	O

of	O
the	O
tumors	O
or	O
with	O
desmin	B-GENE
immunoreactivity	O
.	O

.	O

Ganglioglioma	O
in	O

32610	O
.	O
The	O
entity	O
ganglioglioma	O
in	O
children	O
seems	O
to	O
be	O
an	O
increasingly	O
more	O
common	O
tumor	O
.	O
Most	O
of	O
these	O
lesions	O
are	O
pathologically	O
and	O

benign	O
but	O
have	O
a	O

and	O
clinical	O
continuum	O
in	O
their	O
behavior	O
.	O
Gross	O
total	O
resection	O
,	O
especially	O
involving	O
the	O
lesions	O
in	O
the	O
supratentorial	O
compartment	O

is	O
often	O
curative	O
.	O
The	O
most	O

,	O

in	O
this	O
group	O
of	O
lesions	O

can	O

with	O
removal	O
of	O
the	O
tumor	O
.	O

may	O
be	O
enhanced	O
with	O
the	O
use	O
of	O
corticography	O
at	O
the	O
initial	O
surgery	O
.	O
The	O
group	O
of	O
lesions	O
located	O
in	O
the	O
brainstem	O
are	O
more	O
difficult	O
to	O
control	O
and	O
may	O
require	O

operations	O
and	O
other	O

including	O
radiation	O
and	O
chemotherapy	O
for	O
optimum	O
outcome	O
.	O
Malignant	O
lesions	O
in	O
the	O
ganglioglioma	O
series	O
are	O
rare	O
and	O
optimum	O
therapy	O
for	O
these	O
tumors	O
is	O
not	O
well	O
defined	O
at	O
this	O
time	O
.	O
Pathologically	O
,	O
this	O
group	O
of	O
tumors	O
needs	O
better	O
definition	O
for	O
designing	O
the	O
best	O
therapy	O
.	O

are	O
planning	O
a	O

both	O

and	O
prospectively	O
with	O
flow	O

and	O

such	O
as	O
the	O
K	B-GENE
167	I-GENE
proliferation	I-GENE
antigen	I-GENE
to	O

potential	O

behavior	O
.	O

a	O
broader	O

New	O

approaches	O
are	O
needed	O
for	O
advanced	O
neuroblastoma	O
as	O
few	O
patients	O
are	O
currently	O

.	O
We	O
describe	O
an	O

strategy	O
combining	O
[	O
131I	O
]	O
meta	O
-	O
iodobenzylguanidine	O
(	O
[	O
131I	O
]	O
mIBG	O
)	O
therapy	O
with	O
high	O
dose	O
chemotherapy	O
and	O
total	O
body	O
irradiation	O
.	O

aim	O
of	O

these	O
treatments	O
is	O
to	O
overcome	O
the	O
specific	O
limitations	O
of	O
each	O

alone	O
to	O

of	O
neuroblastoma	O
cells	O
.	O

received	O

with	O
[	O
131I	O
]	O
mIBG	O
followed	O
by	O
high	O
dose	O
melphalan	O
and	O
fractionated	O
total	O
body	O
irradiation	O
.	O
Autologous	O
bone	O
marrow	O
transplantation	O
was	O
undertaken	O
in	O
3	O
patients	O
and	O
allogeneic	O
in	O
2	O
patients	O
.	O
One	O
patient	O
received	O
additional	O
localised	O
radiotherapy	O
to	O
residual	O
bulk	O
disease	O
.	O
One	O
patient	O
is	O
alive	O
without	O
relapse	O
32	O
months	O
after	O
treatment	O
.	O
4	O
patients	O
relapsed	O
after	O
remissions	O
of	O
9	O
,	O
10	O
,	O
14	O
and	O
21	O
months	O
.	O

results	O
indicate	O
that	O
this	O
combined	O
modality	O

Glia	B-GENE
-	I-GENE
derived	I-GENE

(	O

)	O

also	O
known	O
as	O

of	O

can	O

is	O

in	O
all	O

of	O

where	O

of	O
the	O

released	O

.	O

Peripheral	O
neuroblastic	O
tumors	O
(	O

)	O
,	O
are	O
heterogeneous	O
neoplasms	O
that	O
include	O
neuroblastoma	O
(	O

)	O

and	O

(	O

.	O
Two	O
morphologically	O
distinct	O
types	O
of	O
cells	O
have	O
been	O
observed	O
in	O
cultures	O
of	O
human	O
neuroblastoma	O
cells	O
.	O
One	O
,	O
designated	O
N	O
-	O
type	O
,	O
is	O
composed	O
of	O
small	O
neuroblast	O
-	O
like	O
cells	O
;	O
the	O
other	O
,	O
designated	O
S	O
-	O
type	O
,	O
is	O
composed	O
of	O
large	O
,	O
substrate	O
-	O
adherent	O
cells	O
.	O

obtain	O
additional	O
information	O
on	O
the	O
nature	O
of	O
these	O
two	O
phenotypes	O

we	O
have	O
investigated	O

collagen	B-GENE

in	O
several	O
clones	O
of	O
human	O
neuroblastoma	O
cells	O
with	O
N	O
-	O
type	O
,	O
S	O
-	O
type	O
,	O
or	O
mixed	O
morphology	O
,	O
using	O
acrylamide	O
gel	O
electrophoresis	O
,	O
ion	O
exchange	O
chromatography	O
,	O
and	O
Northern	O
and	O
Southern	O
blots	O
.	O
A	O
direct	O
correlation	O
between	O
the	O
proportion	O
of	O
cells	O

-	O
type	O

the	O

of	O
collagen	B-GENE

was	O
observed	O

of	O

being	O
produced	O
by	O
clones	O
composed	O
exclusively	O
of	O
S	O
-	O
type	O
cells	O
.	O

(	I-GENE

of	O

.	O

-	I-GENE

BACKGROUND	O
:	O
Neuroblastomas	O
(	O
NB	O
)	O
are	O
a	O
heterogeneous	O
group	O
of	O
childhood	O
tumours	O
with	O
a	O
wide	O
range	O
of	O
likelihood	O
for	O
tumour	O
progression	O
.	O
As	O
traditional	O
parameters	O
do	O
not	O
ensure	O
completely	O
accurate	O
prognostic	O
grouping	O
,	O
new	O
molecular	O
markers	O
are	O
needed	O
for	O
assessing	O
the	O
individual	O
patient	O
'	O
s	O
prognosis	O
more	O
precisely	O
.	O
PATIENTS	O
AND	O
METHODS	O
:	O
133	O
NB	O
of	O
all	O
stages	O
were	O
analysed	O
in	O
blind	O
-	O
trial	O
fashion	O
for	O
telomerase	B-GENE
activity	O
(	O
TA	O
)	O
,	O
expression	O
of	O
surviving	O
,	O
and	O
MYCN	B-GENE
status	O
.	O
These	O
data	O
were	O
correlated	O
with	O
other	O
traditional	O
prognostic	O
indicators	O
and	O
disease	O
outcome	O
.	O
RESULTS	O
AND	O
CONCLUSIONS	O
:	O
TA	O
is	O
a	O
powerful	O
independent	O
prognostic	O
marker	O
for	O
all	O
stages	O
and	O
is	O
capable	O
of	O
differentiating	O
between	O
good	O
and	O
poor	O
outcome	O
in	O
putative	O
"	O
favourable	O
"	O
clinical	O
or	O
biological	O
subgroups	O
of	O
NB	O
patients	O
.	O
High	O
surviving	O
expression	O
is	O
associated	O
with	O
an	O
adverse	O
outcome	O
,	O
but	O
is	O
more	O
difficult	O
to	O
interprete	O
than	O
TA	O
because	O
survivin	B-GENE
expression	O
needs	O
to	O
be	O
accurately	O
quantified	O
to	O
be	O
of	O
predictive	O
value	O
.	O
We	O
propose	O
an	O
extended	O
progression	O
model	O
for	O
NB	O
including	O
emerging	O
prognostic	O
markers	O
,	O
with	O
emphasis	O
on	O
telomerase	B-GENE
activity	O
.	O

:	O

Insulin	B-GENE
-	I-GENE
like	I-GENE
growth	I-GENE
factors	I-GENE
(	O
IGF-	B-GENE
I	I-GENE
and	O
IGF-II	B-GENE
)	O
are	O
mitogenic	O
polypeptides	O
that	O
play	O
an	O
important	O
role	O
in	O
normal	O
growth	O
and	O
development	O
.	O
IGF-II	B-GENE
has	O
been	O
shown	O
to	O
stimulate	O
the	O
growth	O
of	O
neuroblastoma	O
tumors	O
in	O
an	O

and	O

fashion	O
.	O

of	O

in	O

and	O
tumor	O

.	O

date	O

factors	O
are	O
poorly	O
characterized	O
.	O
In	O
this	O
study	O
we	O
find	O
that	O
retinoic	O
acid	O
(	O
RA	O
)	O
,	O
a	O
naturally	O
occurring	O
morphogen	O
,	O
that	O
has	O
been	O
shown	O
to	O
be	O
indispensable	O
in	O
the	O
development	O
of	O
the	O
chick	O
limb	O
bud	O
,	O
stimulates	O
an	O
increase	O
in	O
IGF-II	B-GENE
messenger	O
RNA	O
(	O
mRNA	O
)	O
in	O
the	O
Lan-	O
1-15N	O
neuroblastoma	O
cell	O
line	O
.	O
This	O

IGF-II	B-GENE
is	O

with	O
RA	O
mediated	O
inhibition	O
of	O

.	O

h	O

new	O

For	O
targeted	O
radionuclide	O
therapy	O
to	O
succeed	O
as	O
a	O
single	O
modality	O
treatment	O

must	O
be	O

which	O
will	O
enable	O
the	O
deposition	O
in	O

of	O
radiation	O
.	O
Until	O
such	O
methods	O
have	O
been	O

it	O
is	O
necessary	O
to	O
combine	O
targeted	O

in	O
a	O

with	O
conventional	O
anti-cancer	O
treatments	O
.	O
Several	O

of	O

of	O

but	O

:	O

[131I]iodide	O

of	O

[131I]meta-iodobenzylguanidine	O
(	O
[131I]MIBG	O
)	O
is	O
an	O

for	O

of	O

that	O
this	O

alone	O
is	O
unlikely	O
to	O
cure	O
disease	O
.	O
A	O
growing	O
body	O
of	O
experimental	O
evidence	O
indicates	O
exciting	O

for	O

of	O

.	O

Many	O

have	O

free	O

(	O

in	O

synapse	O

and	O
patterning	O
.	O

suggest	O
that	O

may	O

.	O

(	O
NOS	B-GENE
)	O

of	O
a	O

phenotype	O
.	O

also	O
been	O

invertebrate	O

systems	O

.	O

Human	O
neuroblastoma	O
(	O
NB	O
)	O
is	O
a	O
highly	O
malignant	O
tumor	O
arising	O
in	O
cells	O
that	O
originate	O
in	O
the	O
embryonal	O
neural	O
crest	O
.	O
Several	O
lines	O
of	O
investigation	O
suggest	O
that	O
both	O
NB	O
and	O
other	O
tumors	O
of	O
developing	O
tissues	O
are	O
blocked	O
in	O
their	O
ability	O
to	O
differentiate	O
and	O
achieve	O
growth	O
arrest	O
.	O
Since	O
in	O
vivo	O
differentiation	O
of	O
NB	O
has	O
been	O
frequently	O
observed	O
and	O
may	O
be	O
of	O
clinical	O
importance	O
(	O
Fox	O
et	O
al.	O
,	O
1959	O
;	O
Evans	O
et	O
al.	O
,	O
1976	O
)	O

we	O
have	O
utilized	O
the	O
in	O
vitro	O
induction	O
of	O
NB	O
differentiation	O
by	O
retinoic	O
acid	O
(	O
RA	O
)	O
to	O
study	O
the	O
molecular	O
events	O
associated	O
with	O
NB	O
differentiation	O
.	O
We	O
have	O
focused	O
our	O
studies	O
on	O
changes	O
that	O
occur	O
in	O
the	O
expression	O
of	O
various	O
proto	O
-	O
oncogenes	O
during	O
NB	O
tumors	O
cell	O
differentiation	O
because	O
proto	O
-	O
oncogenes	O
are	O
likely	O
to	O
be	O
of	O
central	O
importance	O
in	O
mediating	O
processes	O

for	O
cellular	O
growth	O

we	O
have	O
found	O
that	O
the	O
expression	O
of	O
no	O
fewer	O
than	O
five	O
proto	O
-	O

including	O

,	O
c-ets	B-GENE
-1	I-GENE
,	O
and	O
c-	B-GENE

change	O
during	O
the	O

of	O
NB	O
cells	O

while	O
the	O
expression	O
of	O

occurs	O

-	O

lost	O

demonstrated	O

inherited	O
1p	O

in	O

)	O

amplification	O
.	O

amplification	O

the	O

1p	O

of	O

=	O

(	O

)	O

.	O
The	O
role	O
of	O
K(+)	O
channel	O
activity	O
during	O
cell	O
cycle	O
progression	O
has	O
become	O
a	O
research	O
topic	O
of	O
considerable	O
interest	O
.	O
Blocking	O
of	O
K(+)	O
channels	O
inhibits	O
the	O
proliferation	O
of	O
many	O
cell	O
types	O
,	O
although	O

of	O
this	O

is	O
unclear	O
.	O

is	O

that	O

channels	O
differentially	O
regulate	O
the	O

potential	O
of	O
the	O
plasma	O
membrane	O
(	O
V	O
(	O
m	O
)	O
)	O
during	O
proliferation	O
.	O
We	O
have	O

that	O
in	O
tumor	O
cells	O
the	O
value	O
of	O
V	O
(	O

is	O
clamped	O
to	O
rather	O
depolarized	O
values	O
by	O
K(+)	O
channels	O

to	O
the	O
HERG	B-GENE
family	O
.	O
We	O
report	O
here	O
that	O
tumor	O

preferentially	O
express	O

gene	O
and	O
a	O
truncated	O
,	O
N	O
-	O
deleted	O
form	O
that	O
corresponds	O
to	O
herg1b	B-GENE
.	O
This	O

transcript	O
is	O
also	O
expressed	O
in	O
human	O
primary	O
acute	O
myeloid	O
leukemias	O

and	O

can	O
form	O

.	O

of	O

protein	O
isoforms	O
is	O
strongly	O
cell	O
cycle	O
-	O
dependent	O

for	O
variations	O
in	O
HERG	B-GENE
currents	O
along	O
the	O
mitotic	O

.	O

channels	O

of	O

DCC	B-GENE
,	O
a	O
candidate	O
tumor	O
suppressor	O
gene	O
from	O
chromosome	O
18q21	O
,	O
is	O
most	O
highly	O
expressed	O
in	O
the	O
developing	O
nervous	O
system	O
.	O
In	O
vitro	O
studies	O
suggest	O
a	O
role	O
for	O
DCC	B-GENE
in	O
neuronal	O
differentiation	O
,	O
and	O
18q	O
allelic	O
loss	O
occurs	O
in	O
a	O
subset	O
of	O
neuroblastomas	O
.	O
To	O
address	O
the	O
hypothesis	O
that	O
loss	O
of	O
DCC	B-GENE
function	O
may	O
contribute	O
to	O
tumorigenesis	O
in	O
cells	O
of	O
neural	O
origin	O
,	O
we	O
utilized	O
a	O
combination	O
of	O
RNase	B-GENE
protection	O
,	O
immunoblotting	O
,	O
and	O
immunohistochemical	O
approaches	O
to	O
characterize	O
DCC	B-GENE
expression	O
in	O
62	O
primary	O
neuroblastomas	O
and	O
16	O
neuroblastoma	O
cell	O
lines	O
.	O
The	O
DCC	B-GENE
protein	O
was	O
undetectable	O
in	O
38	O
%	O
of	O
the	O
primary	O
tumors	O
and	O
56	O
%	O
of	O
the	O
cell	O
lines	O
.	O
Of	O
note	O
,	O
primary	O
tumors	O
lacking	O
DCC	B-GENE
expression	O
were	O
more	O
likely	O
to	O
have	O
been	O
obtained	O
from	O
patients	O
with	O
disseminated	O
or	O
stage	O
D	O
disease	O
(	O
P	O
=	O
0.01	O
)	O
.	O
In	O
addition	O
,	O
loss	O
of	O
DCC	B-GENE
expression	O
was	O
observed	O
in	O
three	O
of	O
six	O
primary	O
tumors	O
from	O
stage	O
DS	O
patients	O
.	O
No	O
consistent	O
relationship	O
between	O
the	O
loss	O
of	O
DCC	B-GENE
expression	O
and	O
N-myc	B-GENE
amplification	O
was	O
observed	O
in	O
our	O
studies	O
.	O
Our	O

suggest	O
that	O

BACKGROUND	O
:	O
Neuroblastoma	O
is	O
the	O
most	O
common	O
malignant	O
solid	O
tumor	O
in	O
early	O
childhood	O
.	O
Whether	O
neuroblastoma	O
is	O
diagnosed	O
by	O
mass	O
screening	O
or	O
by	O
clinical	O
symptom	O
,	O
it	O
has	O
been	O
reported	O
to	O
be	O
correlated	O
with	O
prognosis	O
of	O
the	O
disease	O
.	O
The	O
periostin	B-GENE
protein	O
shares	O
structural	O
and	O
sequence	O
homology	O
with	O
fasciclin	B-GENE
I	I-GENE
,	O
which	O
is	O
an	O
insect	O
adhesion	O
molecule	O
.	O
METHODS	O
:	O
Expression	O
of	O
periostin	B-GENE
messenger	O
RNAs	O
were	O
evaluated	O
by	O
real	O
-time	O
reverse	O
transcription	O
polymerase	B-GENE
chain	O
reaction	O
(	O
RT-PCR	O
)	O
assay	O
in	O
24	O
tumor	O
samples	O
from	O
neuroblastoma	O
using	O
LightCycler	O
.	O
The	O
data	O
were	O
analyzed	O
in	O
reference	O
to	O
clinicopathologic	O
factors	O
.	O
RESULTS	O
:	O
There	O
was	O
a	O
tendency	O
for	O
higher	O
periostin	B-GENE
transcripts	O
levels	O
in	O
the	O
tumor	O
samples	O
from	O
stage	O
IV	O
when	O
compared	O
with	O
the	O
stage	O
I	O
(	O
P	O
=	O
.0845	O
)	O
.	O
The	O
periostin	B-GENE
mRNA	O
level	O
was	O
higher	O
in	O
the	O
group	O
with	O
disease	O
diagnosed	O
by	O
symptom	O
than	O
in	O
the	O
group	O
with	O
disease	O
diagnosed	O
by	O
mass	O
screening	O
(	O
P	O
=	O
.0266	O
)	O
.	O
The	O
periostin	B-GENE
mRNA	O
level	O
also	O
was	O
higher	O
in	O
the	O
group	O
with	O
disease	O
diagnosed	O
after	O
1	O
year	O
of	O
age	O
than	O
in	O
the	O
group	O
with	O
disease	O
diagnosed	O
before	O
1	O
year	O
of	O
age	O
(	O
P	O
=	O
.0059	O
)	O
.	O

:	O

.	O
Unlike	O
13-cis	O
-	O
retinoic	O
acid	O
,	O
the	O
synthetic	O
retinoid	O
fenretinide	O
[	O
N-(4-hydroxyphenyl)retinamide	O
]	O
induces	O
apoptosis	O
of	O
neuroblastoma	O
cells	O
by	O
mechanisms	O
involving	O
retinoic	B-GENE
acid	I-GENE
receptors	I-GENE
and	O
oxidative	O
stress	O
.	O
After	O
screening	O
a	O
cDNA	O
array	O
for	O
apoptosis	O
-	O
related	O
genes	O
,	O
the	O
Bcl2	B-GENE
-	O
related	O
protein	O
Bak	B-GENE
was	O
identified	O
as	O
a	O
fenretinide	O
-	O
inducible	O
gene	O
in	O
SH-SY5Y	O
neuroblastoma	O
cells	O
,	O
and	O
this	O
was	O
confirmed	O
by	O
Western	O
blotting	O
and	O
flow	O
cytometry	O
.	O
Although	O
fenretinide	O
acts	O
synergistically	O
in	O
vitro	O
with	O
chemotherapeutic	O
drugs	O
,	O
these	O
drugs	O
did	O
not	O
induce	O
Bak	B-GENE
expression	O
.	O
Retinoic	B-GENE
acid	I-GENE
receptor	I-GENE
antagonists	O
did	O
not	O
block	O
the	O
induction	O
of	O
Bak	B-GENE
by	O
fenretinide	O
.	O
Conversely	O
,	O
Bak	B-GENE
induction	O
was	O
blocked	O
by	O
the	O
antioxidant	O
vitamin	O
C	O
.	O
Overexpression	O
of	O
Bak	B-GENE
increased	O
apoptosis	O
in	O
both	O
the	O
presence	O
and	O
absence	O
of	O
fenretinide	O
,	O
whereas	O
expression	O
of	O
antisense	O
Bak	B-GENE
inhibited	O
fenretinide	O
-	O
induced	O
apoptosis	O
.	O
Bak	B-GENE
expression	O
was	O
also	O
induced	O
in	O
cells	O
overexpressing	O
the	O
stress	O
-	O
induced	O
transcription	O
factor	O
GADD153	B-GENE
,	O
but	O
Bak	B-GENE
expression	O
was	O
inhibited	O
in	O
cells	O
expressing	O
an	O
antisense	O
GADD153	B-GENE
construct	O
.	O
These	O
results	O
suggest	O
that	O
Bak	B-GENE
is	O
a	O
downstream	O
mediator	O
of	O
an	O
oxidative	O
stress	O

leading	O
to	O
apoptosis	O
of	O
SH-SY5Y	O
neuroblastoma	O
cells	O
in	O
response	O
to	O
fenretinide	O
.	O

central	O
nervous	O
system	O
containing	O
neoplastic	O
ganglion	O
and	O
low	O
grade	O
glial	O
cells	O
.	O
In	O
studying	O
10	O
surgically	O
treated	O
cases	O

we	O
evaluated	O
the	O
clinical	O
,	O
pathological	O

radiological	O

and	O
immunocytochemical	O
features	O

with	O
follow-up	O
.	O

from	O
18	O
to	O
58	O
years	O
in	O
age	O
,	O
7	O
patients	O
were	O
women	O
,	O
and	O
3	O
were	O
men	O
.	O
The	O

symptom	O
was	O
seizure	O
.	O

scan	O
showed	O
a	O
low	O
density	O

mass	O
in	O
8	O

had	O

abnormal	O

on	O
angiography	O
.	O

patients	O
had	O
total	O
and	O

had	O
subtotal	O
resections	O
of	O
the	O
tumor	O
.	O

was	O
the	O

of	O

6	O
cases	O

for	O

7	O

also	O
seizure	O

free	O
.	O

after	O

one	O
immediately	O
and	O
the	O

that	O

survival	O
.	O

histological	O
makeup	O
is	O
not	O
a	O
definite	O
indication	O
of	O
malignant	O
potential	O

.	O
Shc	B-GENE

.	O

selectively	O

Neuroblastoma	O
is	O
a	O
peripheral	O
nervous	O
system	O
tumor	O
that	O
accounts	O
for	O
8-	O
10	O
%	O
of	O
all	O
solid	O
childhood	O
tumors	O
.	O
N-Myc	B-GENE
is	O
the	O
most	O
reliable	O
prognostic	O
indicator	O
for	O
neuroblastoma	O
.	O
Bcl-2	B-GENE
is	O
detected	O
in	O
40	O
-	O
60	O
%	O
of	O
primary	O
neuroblastoma	O
tumors	O
and	O
demonstrates	O
anti	O
-	O
apoptotic	O
action	O
by	O
conferring	O
resistance	O
to	O
chemotherapy	O
and	O

treatment	O
.	O

neuroblastoma	O
cell	O
lines	O

the	O
coexpression	O
of	O
N-Myc	B-GENE
and	O
Bcl-2	B-GENE
leads	O
to	O
increased	O
tumorigenic	O
properties	O
.	O
Matrix	B-GENE
metalloproteinases	I-GENE
(	O
MMPs	B-GENE
)	O
are	O
endopeptidases	B-GENE
that	O
degrade	O
a	O
wide	O
range	O
of	O
basement	O
membrane	O
components	O

a	O
process	O
important	O
for	O
tumor	O
invasion	O
.	O
This	O
study	O
investigates	O
the	O
effect	O
of	O
N-Myc	B-GENE
and	O
Bcl-2	B-GENE
on	O
MMP	B-GENE
expression	O
and	O
activation	O
.	O

expression	O
and	O
secretion	O
are	O
increased	O
in	O
SHEP	O
neuroblastoma	O
cells	O
expressing	O
Bcl-2	B-GENE
alone	O
(	O
SHEP	O

cells	O
)	O

both	O

and	O
Bcl-2	B-GENE
(	O
SHEP	O
/	O
N-Myc	B-GENE
/	O
Bcl-2	B-GENE
cells	O

Midkine	B-GENE
(	O
MK	B-GENE
)	O
is	O
a	O
newly	O
identified	O
heparin	O
-	O
binding	O
growth	O
factor	O
that	O
is	O
transiently	O
expressed	O
in	O
the	O
early	O
stages	O
of	O
retinoic	O
acid	O
-	O
induced	O
differentiation	O
of	O
embryonal	O
carcinoma	O
cells	O
.	O

has	O
been	O
reported	O
that	O
many	O
human	O
malignant	O
tumors	O
express	O
high	O
levels	O
of	O
MK	B-GENE
mRNA	O
or	O
protein	O
.	O
However	O
,	O
no	O
MK	B-GENE
expression	O
is	O
detected	O
in	O
human	O
or	O
mouse	O
liver	O
.	O

of	O

to	O
examine	O
the	O

promoter	I-GENE
as	O
a	O
candidate	O
for	O
tumor	O
-	O
specific	O
gene	O
expression	O
.	O

thus	O

new	O
recombinant	O
adenoviral	O
(	O
Ad	O
)	O
vectors	O
containing	O
either	O
luciferase	B-GENE
reporter	I-GENE
gene	O
(	O
AdMKLuc	O
)	O
or	O
herpes	B-GENE
simplex	I-GENE

gene	O
(	O

)	O

relatively	O

(	O

and	O

cell	O

to	O

of	O

observed	O
in	O

Neuroblastoma	O
is	O
a	O

tumour	O
and	O
its	O

is	O

of	O
patients	O

oncogene	O

to	O

a	O

.	O

order	O

in	O
non	O

(	O

four	O

that	O

(	O

3	O

4	O

and	O

(	O

3p	O

4p	O
and/or	O

,	O

In	O

(	O

)	O

denoted	O

,	O

.	O

Tumors	O
of	O
the	O
peripheral	O
nervous	O
system	O
include	O
neuroblastomas	O
,	O
pheochromocytomas	O
,	O
and	O
neuroepitheliomas	O
.	O
Neuroblastomas	O
and	O
pheochromocytomas	O
are	O
adrenergic	O
in	O
origin	O
and	O
share	O
certain	O
genetic	O
features	O
,	O
whereas	O
neuroepitheliomas	O
are	O
thought	O
to	O
be	O
cholinergic	O
and	O
are	O
characterized	O
by	O
distinct	O
genetic	O
features	O
.	O
Neuroblastomas	O
are	O
characterized	O
by	O
deletion	O
of	O
the	O
short	O
arm	O
of	O
chromosome	O
1	O
(	O
1p	O
)	O
,	O
amplification	O
of	O
the	O
MYCN	B-GENE
proto	O
-	O
oncogene	O
,	O
and	O
hyperdiploidy	O
in	O
subsets	O
of	O
tumors	O
.	O
All	O
three	O
of	O
these	O
genetic	O
features	O
have	O
prognostic	O
value	O
in	O
subsets	O
of	O
patients	O
.	O
Allelic	O
loss	O
of	O
14q	O
also	O
occurs	O
with	O
increased	O
frequency	O
,	O
but	O
the	O
prognostic	O
importance	O
of	O
this	O

is	O
not	O
known	O
yet	O
.	O
Pheochromocytomas	O
have	O
not	O
been	O
studied	O
as	O
extensively	O
,	O
but	O
allelic	O
loss	O
for	O
1p	O
appears	O
to	O
be	O
a	O
frequent	O
change	O
,	O
and	O
no	O
clear	O

of	O
oncogene	O
activation	O
have	O
been	O
identified	O
to	O
date	O
.	O
Neuroepitheliomas	O
are	O
characterized	O
by	O
translocation	O
between	O
chromosomes	O
11	O
and	O
22	O
.	O

have	O

of	O

-	O

expression	O
,	O
it	O
is	O
not	O
clear	O
that	O
any	O
of	O
these	O
oncogenes	O
are	O
activated	O
specifically	O
,	O
and	O
no	O
sites	O
of	O
allelic	O
loss	O
have	O
been	O
identified	O
to	O
date	O
.	O

,	O

and	O

BACKGROUND	O
:	O
We	O
first	O

to	O

.	O
Sixty	O
-seven	O

(	O
NB	O

phosphoesterases	I-GENE
.	O

and	O

characteristics	O
.	O
At	O

present	O

two	O
hypotheses	O
can	O

to	O

.	O

neuroblastoma	O

from	O
early	O

for	O
analysis	O

Cystatin	B-GENE
B	I-GENE
is	O
an	O
anti	O
-	O
protease	B-GENE
implicated	O
in	O
myoclonus	O
epilepsy	O
,	O
a	O
degenerative	O
disease	O
of	O
the	O
central	O
nervous	O
system	O
.	O
In	O
vitro	O
,	O
cystatin	B-GENE
B	I-GENE
interacts	O
with	O
and	O
inhibits	O
proteases	B-GENE
of	O
the	O
cathepsin	B-GENE
family	O
.	O
Confocal	O
microscopy	O
analysis	O
of	O
the	O
subcellular	O
localization	O
of	O
cystatin	B-GENE
B	I-GENE
and	O
cathepsin	B-GENE
B	I-GENE
shows	O
that	O
,	O
in	O
vivo	O

proteins	O
are	O

fact	O
,	O
cystatin	B-GENE
B	I-GENE
is	O
found	O
mainly	O
in	O
the	O
nucleus	O
of	O

cells	O
and	O
both	O

nucleus	O
and	O
in	O
the	O
cytoplasm	O
of	O
differentiated	O
cells	O

while	O
cathepsin	B-GENE
B	I-GENE
,	O
in	O
either	O
case	O

is	O
essentially	O
cytoplasmic	O
.	O

of	O
cystatin	B-GENE
and	O
cathepsin	B-GENE
B	I-GENE
is	O
observed	O
in	O
the	O
isolated	O
cell	O
matrix	O
and	O
in	O
the	O
nuclear	O
scaffold	O
of	O
differentiated	O
neuroblastoma	O
cells	O
but	O
not	O
of	O
proliferating	O
cells	O
.	O
This	O
suggests	O
that	O
at	O
least	O
a	O
fraction	O
of	O
cystatin	B-GENE
B	I-GENE
is	O
bound	O
to	O
the	O
protease	B-GENE
in	O
differentiated	O
cells	O
.	O
The	O
electron	O
microscopy	O
analysis	O
of	O
the	O
cell	O
matrix	O
confirms	O
the	O
observation	O
made	O
with	O
confocal	O
microscopy	O
.	O
The	O
cellular	O
activity	O
of	O
cathepsin	B-GENE
B	I-GENE
was	O
analyzed	O
with	O
a	O
fluorogenic	O
cytochemical	O
assay	O
.	O

signal	O
is	O
observed	O

of	O

of	O

cells	O

that	O

is	O

during	O
the	O
cell	O
cycle	O
.	O

.	O
Farnesyltransferase	B-GENE
inhibitor	O
FTI-277	O
prevents	O
autocrine	O
growth	O
stimulation	O
of	O
neuroblastoma	O
by	O
BDNF	B-GENE
.	O
Girgert	O
R	O
,	O
Wittrock	O
J,	O
Pfister	O
S	O
,	O
Schweizer	O
P.	O
Department	O
of	O
Gynecology	O
and	O
Obstetrics	O
,	O
University	O
of	O
Ulm	O
,	O
Prittwitzstrasse	O
43	O
,	O
89075	O
,	O
Ulm	O
,	O
Germany	O
.	O
rainer	O
.girgert@medizin	O
.uni-ulm	O
.de	O
PURPOSE	O
:	O
Autocrine	O
growth	O
stimulation	O
by	O
IGF-II	B-GENE
and	O
BDNF	B-GENE
is	O
frequently	O
observed	O
in	O
neuroblastoma	O
.	O
The	O
signals	O
of	O
the	O
receptors	O
of	O
these	O
growth	O
factors	O
are	O
transduced	O
to	O
the	O
nucleus	O
via	O
the	O
Ras	B-GENE
-	O
MAP	B-GENE
-	O
kinase	B-GENE
pathway	O
where	O
they	O
induce	O
proliferation	O
.	O
Inactivation	O
of	O
Ras	B-GENE
-	O
proteins	O
by	O
farnesyltransferase	B-GENE
inhibitors	O
such	O
as	O
FTI-277	O
disrupts	O
growth	O
stimulation	O
of	O
ras	B-GENE
-	O
transformed	O
cells	O
.	O
We	O
investigated	O
whether	O
FTI-277	O
is	O
also	O
active	O
against	O
tumor	O
cells	O
with	O
constitutively	O
activated	O
growth	B-GENE
factor	I-GENE
receptors	I-GENE
but	O
lacking	O
ras	B-GENE
-	O
mutations	O
.	O
METHOD	O
:	O
We	O
analyzed	O
eight	O
different	O
neuroblastoma	O
cell	O
lines	O
for	O
the	O
expression	O
of	O
BDNF	B-GENE
and	O
its	O
receptor	O
trkB	B-GENE
.	O
Two	O
of	O
these	O
cell	O
lines	O
with	O
a	O
complete	O
autocrine	O
BDNF	O
loop	O
were	O
treated	O
with	O
FTI-277	O
,	O
and	O
the	O
effects	O
of	O
Ras	B-GENE
-	O
inactivation	O
on	O
the	O
signal	O
transduction	O
of	O
BDNF	O
were	O
analyzed	O
.	O
RESULTS	O
:	O
Treatment	O
of	O
neuroblastoma	O
cells	O
with	O
10	O
microM	O
FTI-277	O
for	O
4	O
days	O
reduced	O
the	O
amount	O
of	O
membrane	O
-bound	O
Ras	B-GENE
-	O
protein	O
to	O
almost	O
50	O
%	O
.	O
Activation	O
of	O
MAP-kinase	B-GENE
,	O
induction	O
of	O
N-myc	B-GENE
expression	O
,	O
and	O
proliferation	O
were	O
clearly	O
reduced	O
in	O
the	O
treated	O
cells	O
.	O
In	O
addition	O
,	O
we	O
observed	O
some	O
cytotoxic	O
effects	O
of	O
FTI-277	O
accompanied	O
by	O
morphological	O
changes	O
of	O
the	O
neuroblastoma	O
cells	O
and	O
a	O
delayed	O
induction	O
of	O
apoptosis	O
.	O
CONCLUSION	O
:	O
Farnesyltransferase	B-GENE
inhibitors	O
are	O
active	O
against	O
neuroblastoma	O
cells	O
but	O
the	O
mechanism	O
of	O
action	O
is	O
not	O
limited	O
to	O
inactivation	O
of	O
Ras	B-GENE
.	O
Further	O
investigations	O
on	O
the	O
targets	O
of	O
FTI-277	O
are	O
recommended	O
.	O

:	O

.	O
Assessment	O
of	O
MYCN	B-GENE
amplification	O
in	O
neuroblastoma	O
biopsies	O
by	O
differential	O
polymerase	B-GENE
chain	O
reaction	O
.	O
Boerner	O
S	O
,	O
Squire	O
J,	O
Thorner	O
P,	O
McKenna	O
G	O
,	O
Zielenska	O
M.	O
Department	O
of	O
Pathology	O
,	O
Hospital	O
for	O
Sick	O
Children	O
,	O
Toronto	O
,	O
Ontario	O
,	O
Canada	O
.	O
Amplification	O
of	O
the	O
oncogene	O
MYCN	B-GENE
is	O
a	O
genetic	O
change	O
frequently	O
observed	O
in	O
neuroblastoma	O
and	O
is	O
an	O
indicator	O
of	O
poor	O
prognosis	O
.	O
MYCN	B-GENE
copy	O
number	O
is	O
currently	O
determined	O
by	O
Southern	O
blot	O
hybridization	O
.	O
This	O
technique	O
takes	O
2	O
to	O
3	O
weeks	O
,	O
is	O
labor	O
-	O
intensive	O
,	O
is	O
sensitive	O
to	O
DNA	O
degradation	O
,	O
and	O
requires	O
large	O
quantities	O
of	O
DNA	O
.	O
We	O
have	O
evaluated	O
a	O
new	O
,	O
semiquantitative	O
method	O
of	O
estimating	O
gene	O
copy	O
number	O
that	O
uses	O
differential	O
polymerase	B-GENE
chain	O
reaction	O
(	O
PCR	O
)	O
.	O
The	O
procedure	O
can	O
be	O
performed	O
in	O
1	O
day	O
,	O
is	O
highly	O
reproducible	O
,	O
and	O
requires	O
only	O
nanogram	O
quantities	O
of	O
DNA	O
.	O
It	O
employs	O
a	O
semiquantitative	O
,	O
nonisotopic	O
PCR	O
technique	O
based	O
on	O
differential	O
competition	O
for	O
PCR	O
substrates	O
.	O
MYCN	B-GENE
gene	O
primers	O
are	O
amplified	O
together	O
with	O
primers	O
from	O
a	O
single-copy	O
internal	O
control	O
gene	O
.	O
Following	O
electrophoretic	O
separation	O
,	O
the	O
ratio	O
of	O
the	O
two	O
PCR	O
products	O
is	O
determined	O
visually	O
and	O
by	O
densitometric	O
analysis	O
of	O
ethidium	O
bromide	O
-	O
stained	O
agarose	O
gels	O
.	O
This	O
differential	O
ratio	O
is	O
then	O
compared	O
to	O
a	O
series	O
of	O
ratios	O
generated	O
from	O
standards	O
of	O
known	O
MYCN	B-GENE
gene	O
copy	O
number	O
.	O
We	O
compared	O
the	O
results	O
obtained	O
by	O
this	O
differential	O
PCR	O
method	O
with	O
those	O
obtained	O
by	O
conventional	O
Southern	O
blotting	O
in	O
16	O
cases	O
of	O
primary	O
neuroblastoma	O
.	O
All	O
amplified	O
tumors	O
were	O
detected	O
by	O
differential	O
PCR	O
,	O
and	O
no	O
false	O
positives	O
were	O
observed	O
.	O
We	O
confirmed	O
that	O
differential	O
PCR	O
is	O
a	O
rapid	O
and	O
reliable	O
alternative	O
to	O
Southern	O
blotting	O
for	O
MYCN	B-GENE
copy	O
number	O
assessment	O
and	O
is	O
highly	O
suited	O
to	O
the	O
analysis	O
of	O
DNA	O
derived	O
from	O
needle	O
biopsies	O
.	O
PMID	O
:	O
7808981	O

.	O
Carbonyl	O

p-	O
trifluoromethoxyphenylhydrazone	O
(	O

)	O
increased	O
the	O

(	O
[Ca(2+)	O
]	O
(i)	O
)	O
and	O
caused	O
cell	O
death	O
.	O
Thapsigargin	O
(	O
TG	O
)	O
not	O
only	O
increased	O
the	O
[	O
Ca(2+)	O
]	O
(i)	O
and	O

cell	O

also	O
induced	O
neurite	O
outgrowth	O
via	O
activation	O
of	O
phospholipase_A	B-GENE
(2	I-GENE
)	I-GENE
and	O
cytochrome	B-GENE
P450	I-GENE
epoxygenase	I-GENE
.	O
In	O
contrast	O
,	O
bradykinin	B-GENE
increased	O
the	O
[	O
Ca(2+)	O
]	O
(i	O
)	O

but	O
had	O
no	O

on	O
cell	O

or	O
cell	O
death	O
.	O

,	O
one	O

was	O
caspase	B-GENE
-3	I-GENE
-	O
dependent	O
and	O
the	O
other	O
caspase	B-GENE
-3	I-GENE
-	O
independent	O
.	O

activation	O
was	O

,	O
whereas	O

outgrowth	O
was	O

TG	O

or	O

-	O

factor	I-GENE

.	O

of	O

about	O

.	O

that	O

of	O

cell	O

,	O
that	O

activates	O

(2	I-GENE
)	I-GENE

Mimosine	O
is	O
a	O

.	O

Ithaca	O

New	O
York	O
14853	O
,	O
USA	O
.	O
Iron	O
deficiency	O
and	O
iron	O
chelators	O
are	O
known	O
to	O
alter	O
folate	O
metabolism	O
in	O
mammals	O
,	O
but	O
the	O
underlying	O
biochemical	O
mechanisms	O
have	O
not	O
been	O
established	O
.	O
Although	O
many	O
studies	O
have	O
demonstrated	O
that	O
the	O
iron	O
chelators	O
mimosine	O
and	O
deferoxamine	O
inhibit	O
DNA	O
replication	O
in	O
mammalian	O
cells	O
,	O
their	O
mechanism	O
of	O
action	O
remains	O
controversial	O
.	O
The	O
effects	O
of	O
mimosine	O
on	O
folate	O
metabolism	O
were	O
investigated	O
in	O
human	O
MCF-7	O
cells	O
and	O
SH-SY5Y	O
neuroblastoma	O
.	O
Our	O
findings	O
indicate	O
that	O
mimosine	O
is	O
a	O
folate	O
antagonist	O
and	O
that	O
its	O
effects	O
are	O
cell	O
-	O
specific	O
.	O
MCF-7	O
cells	O
cultured	O
in	O
the	O
presence	O
of	O
350	O
microm	O
mimosine	O
were	O
growth-arrested	O
,	O
whereas	O
mimosine	O
had	O
no	O
effect	O
on	O
SH-SY5Y	O
cell	O
proliferation	O
.	O
Mimosine	O
altered	O
the	O
distribution	O
of	O
folate	O
cofactor	O
forms	O
in	O
MCF-7	O
cells	O
,	O
indicating	O
that	O
mimosine	O
targets	O
folate	O
metabolism	O
.	O
However	O
,	O
mimosine	O
does	O
not	O
influence	O
folate	O
metabolism	O
in	O
SH-SY5Y	O
neuroblastoma	O
.	O

effect	O
of	O
mimosine	O
on	O
folate	O
metabolism	O
is	O
associated	O
with	O
decreased	O

(	O

AIMS	O
:	O

has	O

a	O

of	O

of	O
some	O

in	O

.	O

Susceptibility	O
to	O
infection	O
by	O
the	O
human	O
polyomavirus	O
,	O
JCV	O
,	O
is	O
determined	O
by	O

which	O
control	O
transcription	O
and	O
replication	O
.	O
Originally	O

to	O
propagate	O
well	O
only	O
in	O
human	O
cells	O
of	O
oligodendroglial	O
lineage	O
,	O

has	O
recently	O
been	O
shown	O
to	O
infect	O
astrocytes	O
,	O
astrogliomas	O
,	O
and	O
a	O
neuroblastoma	O
cell	O
line	O
.	O

data	O
reported	O
here	O
describe	O
two	O
cell	O
types	O
that	O
have	O
been	O
subcultured	O
from	O
a	O
human	O
neuroblastoma	O
cell	O
line	O
,	O
SK-N-SH	O
.	O

subclone	O
displays	O
neuronal	O
phenotypes	O
and	O
is	O
not	O
susceptible	O
to	O
JCV	O
infection	O
,	O
while	O
the	O
SH-EP	O
subclone	O
displays	O
glial	O
cell	O
phenotypes	O
and	O
is	O
susceptible	O
to	O
infection	O
.	O

of	O
nuclear	O
proteins	O
from	O

permissive	O

(	O

)	O

Neuroblastoma	O
,	O
a	O
malignant	O
neoplasm	O
that	O
arises	O
in	O
the	O
adrenal	O
medulla	O
or	O
sympathetic	O
ganglion	O

is	O
one	O
of	O
the	O
most	O
common	O
solid	O
tumors	O
of	O
childhood	O
.	O
Reports	O
that	O
neuroblastomas	O
spontaneously	O
mature	O
to	O
form	O
benign	O
ganglioneuromas	O
have	O
prompted	O

that	O

differentiation	O
in	O

treatment	O
of	O

.	O

acid	O
is	O
one	O
agent	O
in	O

that	O
has	O
been	O
shown	O
to	O

growth	O

cell	O

.	O

the	O

cell	O
line	O

protein	O

in	O

acid	O

.	O

with	O

acid	O
results	O

a	O
rapid	O

(	O
within	O
4	O
h	O
)	O
of	O
thrombospondin	B-GENE
(	O
TSP	B-GENE
)	O
message	O

is	O
independent	O
of	O

protein	O
synthesis	O
and	O

functions	O
as	O

.	O

.	O

-	I-GENE

(	O
[Ca2	O
+	O
]i	O

to	O

accumulation	O
.	O

of	O

oxide	I-GENE
synthase	I-GENE
(	O

)	O

Ca2	O

-	O

of	O

is	O

for	O

in	O
[	O

+	O
]i	O

Metallothionein	B-GENE

the	O

cervix	O
,	O
and	O
in	O
other	O
cases	O

tumor	O
such	O
as	O
chromosomes	O
4	O
and	O

loss	O

These	O
results	O
suggest	O
that	O
there	O

two	O

of	O
tumor	O

whose	O

a	O

cell	O
.	O

an	O

.	O

.	O
Genetic	O
parameters	O
of	O
neuroblastomas	O
.	O
Westermann	O
F	O
,	O
Schwab	O
M.	O
Department	O
of	O
Cytogenetics	O
(	O
H0400	O
)	O
,	O
German	O
Cancer	O
Research	O
Center	O
,	O
Im	O
Neuenheimer	O
Feld	O
280	O
,	O
69120	O
Heidelberg	O
,	O
Germany	O
.	O
f.westermann@dkfz.de	O
Neuroblastoma	O
is	O
a	O
malignant	O
childhood	O
tumor	O
of	O
migrating	O
neuroectodermal	O
cells	O
derived	O
from	O
the	O
neural	O
crest	O
and	O
destined	O
for	O
the	O
adrenal	O
medulla	O
and	O
the	O
sympathetic	O
nervous	O
system	O
.	O
The	O
biological	O
behavior	O
of	O
neuroblastomas	O
is	O
extremely	O
variable	O
and	O
in	O
some	O
respects	O
unique	O
.	O
Neuroblastomas	O
tend	O
to	O
regress	O
spontaneously	O
in	O
a	O
portion	O
of	O
infants	O
or	O
to	O
differentiate	O
into	O
a	O
benign	O
ganglioneuroma	O
in	O
some	O
older	O
patients	O
.	O
Unfortunately	O
,	O
in	O
the	O
majority	O
of	O
patients	O
neuroblastoma	O
is	O
metastatic	O
at	O
the	O
time	O
of	O
diagnosis	O
,	O
and	O
it	O
usually	O
undergoes	O
rapid	O
progression	O
with	O
a	O
fatal	O
outcome	O
.	O
The	O
mechanisms	O
leading	O
to	O
this	O
diverse	O
clinical	O
behavior	O
of	O
neuroblastomas	O
are	O
largely	O
unclear	O
.	O
From	O
the	O
analysis	O
of	O
tumors	O
at	O
the	O
cytogenetic	O
and	O
molecular	O
level	O
non	O
-	O
random	O
genetic	O
changes	O
have	O
been	O
identified	O
,	O
including	O
ploidy	O
changes	O
,	O
amplification	O
of	O
the	O
oncogene	O
MYCN	B-GENE
,	O
deletions	O
of	O
chromosome	O
1p	O
,	O
gains	O
of	O
chromosome	O
arm	O
17q	O
,	O
and	O
deletions	O
of	O
11q	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
of	O
other	O
genomic	O
regions	O
that	O
allow	O
tumors	O
to	O
be	O
classified	O
into	O
subsets	O
with	O
distinct	O
biological	O
features	O
and	O
clinical	O
behavior	O
.	O
MYCN	B-GENE
status	O
is	O
widely	O
accepted	O
for	O
therapy	O
stratification	O
.	O
Additional	O
genetic	O
parameters	O
are	O
currently	O
under	O
investigation	O
to	O
refine	O
risk	O
assessment	O
,	O
but	O
so	O
far	O
the	O
molecular	O
monitoring	O
tools	O
for	O
prediction	O
of	O
therapy	O
response	O
and	O
disease	O
outcome	O
are	O
still	O
incomplete	O
.	O
This	O
should	O
lead	O
to	O
more	O
risk	O
-adapted	O
therapies	O
according	O
to	O
the	O
clinical	O
-	O
genetic	O
parameters	O
by	O
which	O
individual	O
tumors	O
are	O
characterized	O
.	O
This	O
review	O
aims	O
at	O
discussing	O
the	O
role	O
of	O
genomic	O
changes	O
in	O
neuroblastomas	O
of	O
diverse	O
biological	O
and	O
clinical	O
types	O
.	O
Publication	O
Types	O
:	O
Review	O

,	O
Academic	O

:	O

PURPOSE	O
:	O
Neuroblastoma	O
shows	O
remarkable	O
heterogeneity	O
,	O
resulting	O
in	O
favorable	O
or	O
unfavorable	O
outcomes	O
.	O
The	O
authors	O
previously	O
reported	O
that	O
high	O
levels	O
of	O
telomerase	B-GENE
activity	O
correlated	O
with	O
unfavorable	O
tumors	O
,	O
and	O
telomere	O
shortening	O
without	O
telomerase	B-GENE
activity	O
correlated	O
with	O
tumor	O
regression	O
.	O
To	O
identify	O
the	O
genes	O
responsible	O
for	O
the	O
biological	O
characteristics	O
of	O
neuroblastoma	O
,	O
the	O
authors	O
applied	O
microarray	O
techniques	O
.	O
METHODS	O
:	O
Mixtures	O
of	O
total	O
RNAs	O
extracted	O
from	O
10	O
neuroblastoma	O
tissues	O
with	O
high	O
and	O
10	O
with	O
low	O
telomerase	B-GENE
activity	O
were	O
labeled	O
with	O
Cy3	B-GENE
or	O
Cy5	B-GENE
by	O
reverse	B-GENE
transcriptase	I-GENE
reaction	O
,	O
respectively	O
,	O
and	O
hybridized	O
with	O
our	O
original	O
microarrays	O
prepared	O
with	O
a	O
cDNA	O
library	O
of	O
human	O
fetal	O
brain	O
.	O
RESULTS	O
:	O
Expression	O
of	O
63	O
genes	O
including	O
MYCN	B-GENE
,	O
hTERT	B-GENE
,	O
HSPCA	B-GENE
,	O
and	O
cell	O
cycle	O
-	O
related	O
proteins	O
was	O
found	O
to	O
be	O
increased	O
in	O
neuroblastomas	O
with	O
high	O
telomerase	B-GENE
activity	O
,	O
whereas	O
another	O
46	O
genes	O
,	O
including	O
neural	O
differentiating	O
genes	O
,	O
were	O
detected	O
as	O
highly	O
expressed	O
in	O
tumors	O
with	O
low	O
telomerase	B-GENE
activity	O
.	O
CONCLUSIONS	O
:	O

expression	O
profiling	O
data	O
indicated	O
clusters	O
of	O
upregulated	O
and	O
downregulated	O
genes	O

with	O

activity	O
.	O

involved	O
in	O
differentiation	O
/	O
growth	O
arrest	O
of	O
tumor	O
cells	O
were	O
closely	O
related	O
to	O
low	O
telomerase	B-GENE
activity	O
in	O
neuroblastoma	O
.	O

genes	O
overexpressed	O
in	O
tumors	O
with	O
high	O
telomerase	B-GENE
activity	O
,	O
including	O
cell	O

-	O
related	O
genes	O
and	O

factors	O
,	O
would	O
be	O
candidates	O
for	O
novel	O
prognosis	O

predicting	O
factors	O
as	O

.	O
Disseminated	O
neuroblastoma	O
is	O
a	O
malignancy	O
of	O
children	O
often	O
treated	O
by	O
intensive	O
chemotherapy	O
/	O
radiotherapy	O
followed	O
by	O
autologous	O
bone	O
marrow	O
transplantation	O
(	O
ABMT	O
)	O
.	O
A	O
high	O
proportion	O
of	O
those	O
treated	O
subsequently	O
relapse	O
.	O
It	O
is	O
unknown	O
if	O
relapse	O
is	O
a	O
consequence	O
of	O
residual	O
disease	O
in	O
the	O
patient	O
or	O
of	O
contaminating	O
malignant	O
cells	O
remaining	O
in	O
the	O
infused	O
marrow	O
,	O
which	O
,	O
of	O
necessity	O
,	O
is	O
harvested	O
and	O
stored	O
prior	O
to	O
ablative	O
chemotherapy	O
/	O
radiotherapy	O
.	O
The	O
assumption	O
that	O
residual	O
cells	O
in	O
the	O
infused	O
marrow	O
contribute	O
to	O
relapse	O
has	O
lead	O
to	O
the	O
adoption	O
of	O
marrow	O
purging	O
prior	O
to	O
reinfusion	O
.	O
However	O
,	O
neither	O
the	O
necessity	O
nor	O
the	O
efficacy	O
of	O
the	O
procedure	O
have	O
been	O
established	O
.	O
We	O
now	O
show	O
how	O
retroviral	O
-	O
mediated	O
gene	O
transfer	O
using	O
the	O
LNL6	O
vector	O
may	O
resolve	O
this	O
issue	O
.	O
Clonogenic	O
neuroblastoma	O
cells	O
in	O
patient	O
marrow	O
can	O
be	O
transduced	O
and	O
the	O
NEOR	B-GENE
gene	O
detected	O
by	O
observing	O
individual	O
neuroblastoma	O
cell	O
colony	O
growth	O
in	O
G418	O
,	O
and	O
by	O
polymerase	B-GENE
chain	O
reaction	O
(	O
PCR	O
)	O
of	O
individual	O
colonies	O
.	O
Efficiency	O
of	O
transduction	O
is	O
between	O
0	O
and	O
13.5	O
%	O
.	O
If	O
marrow	O
is	O
exposed	O
to	O
LNL6	O
prior	O
to	O
infusion	O
and	O
marked	O

are	O

at	O

relapse	O
,	O
this	O
would	O
demonstrate	O
that	O
infused	O
marrow	O
contributed	O
to	O
disease	O
recurrence	O
.	O
The	O
technique	O
could	O
then	O
be	O
used	O
to	O
analyze	O
the	O
efficacy	O
of	O
marrow	O

.	O

are	O

marked	O

the	O

to	O
study	O
factors	O
that	O
modify	O
reconstitution	O
and	O
transducibility	O
of	O
infused	O
marrow	O
.	O
Clinical	O

approach	O

now	O

Current	O
therapy	O
for	O
children	O
with	O
cancer	O
includes	O
a	O

of	O
invasive	O

many	O

which	O
require	O
repeated	O

access	O
over	O
a	O

period	O
of	O
time	O
.	O
Such	O
procedures	O
are	O
poorly	O
tolerated	O
by	O
children	O
and	O
by	O
their	O
veins	O
.	O
Recently	O
it	O
has	O
become	O
possible	O

undertake	O

we	O
have	O

46	O

and	O

.	O
Neuroblastoma	O
(	O
NB	O
)	O
is	O
a	O
tumor	O
of	O
pediatric	O
age	O
that	O
is	O
associated	O
with	O
high	O
mortality	O
in	O
metastatic	O
stages	O
,	O
although	O
stage	O
IVS	O
patients	O
undergo	O
frequent	O
spontaneous	O
regression	O
.	O
Since	O
apoptosis	O
has	O
been	O

as	O
a	O
possible	O
cause	O
of	O
remission	O
among	O
cancer	O
patients	O

this	O

among	O
both	O
localized	O
and	O
metastatic	O
NB	O
and	O
,	O
in	O
particular	O
,	O
NB	O
metastatic	O
stage	O
IVS	O
.	O
We	O
have	O
assayed	O
36	O
localized	O
and	O
117	O
metastatic	O
neuroblastomas	O
for	O
evidence	O
of	O
internucleosomal	O

and	O
confirmed	O
DNA	O

by	O
the	O
flow	O

method	O

.	O

18	O
out	O
of	O
153	O
samples	O
(	O

.	O

.	O

-	I-GENE

factor	O

(	O

BACKGROUND	O
:	O
Neuroblastomas	O
(	O
NBs	O
)	O
exhibit	O
a	O
wide	O
variety	O
of	O

behavior	O
.	O

is	O
important	O
to	O

the	O
biology	O
of	O

before	O
treatment	O
is	O
instituted	O
.	O
METHODS	O
:	O

hundred	O
six	O

classified	O

to	O

and	O

gene	O

patient	O

of	O

of	O

the	O

was	O
compared	O
with	O

U.S.A	O
.	O
Neuroblastomas	O
demonstrate	O
both	O
clinical	O
and	O
biological	O
heterogeneity	O
.	O
We	O
have	O
proposed	O
that	O
neuroblastomas	O
may	O
be	O
classified	O
in	O
three	O
genetically	O
distinct	O
subtypes	O

based	O
on	O
cytogenetic	O
and	O
molecular	O
analysis	O
.	O
The	O
first	O
comprises	O
those	O
with	O
hyperdiploid	O
or	O
triploid	O
modal	O
karyotypes	O
(	O
or	O
compatible	O
DNA	O
content	O
by	O
flow	O
cytometry	O
)	O
,	O
1p	O
LOH	O
and	O
MYCN	B-GENE
amplification	O
are	O
absent	O
,	O
and	O
TRKA	B-GENE
expression	O
is	O
high	O
.	O
These	O
patients	O
are	O
likely	O
to	O
be	O
infants	O
with	O
low	O
stages	O
of	O
disease	O
(	O
stages	O
1	O
,	O
2	O
,	O
or	O
4S	O
by	O
the	O
International	O
Neuroblastoma	O
Staging	O
System	O
)	O
,	O
and	O
they	O
have	O
a	O
very	O
favourable	O
outcome	O
(	O
>	O
90	O
%	O
cure	O
)	O
.	O
The	O
second	O
group	O
consists	O
of	O
tumours	O
that	O
generally	O
have	O
a	O
near	O
diploid	O
or	O
tetraploid	O
modal	O
chromosome	O
number	O
or	O
DNA	O
content	O
but	O
lack	O
MYCN	B-GENE
amplification	O
.	O

usually	O
have	O
1p	O
allelic	O
loss	O
,	O
14q	O
allelic	O
loss	O
or	O
other	O
structural	O
changes	O
,	O
and	O
TRKA	B-GENE
expression	O
is	O
usually	O
low	O
.	O
These	O
patients	O
are	O
generally	O
older	O
with	O
advanced	O
stages	O
of	O
disease	O
(	O
stages	O
3	O

4	O

usually	O

1	O

5	O

of	O

(	O
<	O
5	O
%	O
)	O

to	O

that	O

genes	O

)	O
was	O
discovered	O
a	O
dozen	O
years	O
ago	O
as	O
a	O
product	O
of	O
malignant	O
tumors	O
.	O
It	O
is	O
now	O
known	O
that	O
PTHrP	B-GENE
is	O
a	O
paracrine	O
factor	O
with	O
multiple	O
biological	O
functions	O
.	O
One	O
such	O
function	O
is	O
to	O
relax	O
smooth	O
muscle	O
by	O
inhibiting	O
calcium	O
influx	O
into	O
the	O
cell	O
.	O
In	O
the	O
central	O
nervous	O
system	O
,	O
PTHrP	B-GENE
and	O
its	O
receptor	B-GENE
are	O
widely	O
expressed	O
in	O
neurons	O
in	O
the	O
cerebral	O
cortex	O
,	O
hippocampus	O
and	O
cerebellum	O
.	O
The	O
function	O
of	O
PTHrP	B-GENE
in	O
the	O
CNS	O
is	O
not	O
known	O
.	O
Previous	O
work	O
has	O
shown	O
that	O
expression	O
of	O
the	O
PTHrP	B-GENE
gene	O
is	O
depolarization	O
-	O
dependent	O
in	O
cultured	O
cerebellar	O
granule	O
cells	O
and	O
depends	O
specifically	O
on	O
L-type	O
voltage	O
sensitive	O
calcium	O
channel	O
(	O
L-VSCC	O
)	O
Ca(2+)	O
influx	O
.	O
PTHrP	B-GENE
has	O
also	O
been	O
found	O
to	O
be	O
capable	O
of	O
protecting	O
these	O
cells	O
against	O
kainic	O
acid	O
-	O
induced	O
excitotoxicity	O
.	O
Here	O
,	O
we	O
tested	O
the	O
idea	O
that	O
mice	O
with	O
a	O
PTHrP	B-GENE
-	O
null	O
CNS	O
might	O
display	O
hypersensitivity	O
to	O
kainic	O
acid	O
excitotoxicity	O
.	O
We	O
found	O
that	O
these	O
mice	O
were	O
six	O
-	O
fold	O
more	O
sensitive	O
than	O
control	O
littermate	O
mice	O
to	O
kainic	O
-acid	O
-	O
induced	O
seizures	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
hippocampal	O
c-Fos	B-GENE
expression	O
.	O
PTHrP	B-GENE
-	O
null	O
embryonic	O
mixed	O
cerebral	O
cortical	O
cultures	O
were	O
more	O
sensitive	O
to	O
kainic	O
acid	O
than	O
control	O
cultures	O
,	O
and	O
PTHrP	B-GENE
addition	O
was	O
found	O
to	O
be	O
protective	O
against	O
kainate	O
toxicity	O
in	O
both	O
PTHrP	B-GENE
-	O
null	O
and	O
control	O
cultures	O
.	O
By	O
whole	O
-	O
cell	O
techniques	O
,	O
PTHrP	B-GENE
was	O
found	O
to	O
reduce	O
L-VSCC	O
Ca(2+)	O
influx	O
in	O
cultured	O
mouse	O
neuroblastoma	O
cells	O
.	O
We	O
conclude	O
that	O
PTHrP	B-GENE
functions	O
as	O
a	O
component	O
of	O
a	O
neuroprotective	O
feedback	O
loop	O
that	O
is	O
structured	O
around	O
the	O
L-type	O
calcium	O
channel	O
.	O

loop	O
appears	O
to	O
be	O
operative	O
in	O
vivo	O
as	O
well	O
as	O
in	O
vitro	O
.	O

Inclusions	O
containing	O
ubiquitin	B-GENE
-	O
protein	O
aggregates	O
appear	O
in	O
neurons	O
of	O

inclusion	O

not	O

we	O

of	O
an	O

rat	O
mesencephalic	O
cultures	O

inhibition	O
of	O
the	O

/	O
proteasome	O
pathway	O
.	O

inhibitors	O

a	O

and	O

found	O
to	O
enhance	O
expression	O
of	O
stress	O
-	O
inducible	O
genes	O

including	O
HSP70i	B-GENE
and	O

genes	O

and	O

.	O

of	O

(	O

with	O
its	O
product	O

a	O
proinflammatory	O

.	O

of	O

contributes	O
to	O
the	O

of	O

protein	O

.	O

with	O
antioxidants	O
known	O
to	O

and	O

to	O

BACKGROUND	O
:	O
Autologous	O
peripheral	O
blood	O
stem	O
cell	O
(	O
PBSCs	O
)	O
are	O
frequently	O
used	O
to	O
reconstitute	O
hematopoiesis	O
following	O
administration	O
of	O
megatherapy	O
in	O
children	O
with	O
advanced	O
stage	O
IV	O
neuroblastoma	O
.	O
Some	O
centers	O
prefer	O
the	O
use	O
of	O
autografts	O
enriched	O
for	O
CD34	B-GENE
+	O
progenitor	O
cells	O
because	O
the	O
positive	O
selection	O
procedure	O
is	O
believed	O
to	O
reduce	O
indirectly	O
tumor	O
cell	O
contamination	O
.	O
PROCEDURES	O
:	O
In	O
this	O
study	O
,	O
we	O
monitored	O
the	O
efficiency	O
of	O
tumor	O
cell	O

following	O

selection	O
in	O

seven	O
patients	O
with	O
advanced	O
neuroblastoma	O
by	O
using	O
a	O
highly	O
sensitive	O
reverse	B-GENE
transcriptase	I-GENE
-	O
polymerase	B-GENE
chain	O
reaction	O
(	O
RT-PCR	O
)	O
analysis	O
,	O
Amplification	O
of	O
tissues	O
-	O
specific	O

transcript	O
of	O
tyrosine	B-GENE
hydroxylase	I-GENE

with	O
nested	O

detection	O
of	O
residual	O
neuroblastoma	O

with	O
a	O
sensitivity	O
of	O
one	O
malignant	O
-	O
cell	O
per	O
10(6)	O
normals	O
.	O

method	O

tumor	O

.	O

six	O

PCR	O

became	O

negative	O
after	O
selection	O
.	O

Lithium	O
and	O
sodium	O

(	O
VPA	O
)	O
are	O
effective	O
in	O
the	O
treatment	O
of	O
bipolar	O
disorder	O
(	O
BD	O
)	O
and	O
may	O
function	O
through	O
the	O
regulation	O
of	O
signal	O
transduction	O
pathways	O
and	O
transcription	O
factors	O
such	O
as	O
c-	B-GENE
fos	I-GENE
and	O
c-Jun	B-GENE
,	O
which	O
in	O
turn	O
results	O
to	O
changes	O
in	O
gene	O
expression	O
.	O

of	O
lithium	O
and	O
VPA	O
in	O

suggests	O
that	O
the	O
regulation	O
of	O
gene	O

may	O
be	O

important	O
target	O
for	O
these	O
drugs	O
.	O

suggests	O
that	O
c-	B-GENE

levels	O
and	O

.	O
However	O

in	O
this	O
technology	O
.	O

on	O
within	O

replications	O

a	O

variations	O
without	O

assumptions	O
.	O
The	O
significant	O
analysis	O
of	O
gene	O
expressions	O
is	O
based	O
on	O
a	O
weighted	O
t	O
statistic	O
,	O

for	O

of	O
the	O

of	O
expressions	O

sign	O

test	O
.	O

BACKGROUND	O
:	O
Angiogenesis	O
is	O
essential	O
for	O
tumor	O
growth	O
and	O
relies	O
on	O
the	O
production	O
of	O
angiogenic	O
factors	O
.	O
Vascular	B-GENE
endothelial	I-GENE
growth	I-GENE
factor	I-GENE
(	O
VEGF	B-GENE
)	O
is	O
a	O
major	O
regulator	O
of	O
angiogenesis	O
that	O
binds	O
to	O
tyrosine	B-GENE
kinase	I-GENE
receptors	I-GENE
Flt-1	I-GENE
and	O
KDR	B-GENE
.	O

interaction	O
of	O
VEGF	B-GENE
and	O
its	O
receptors	B-GENE
at	O
gene	O
and	O
protein	O
levels	O
in	O
neuroblastoma	O
remains	O
widely	O
unknown	O
.	O
METHODS	O
:	O
Tumor	O
biopsy	O
specimens	O

.	O
The	O
p53	B-GENE
gene	O
is	O
the	O
most	O

gene	O
in	O
human	O
cancer	O

and	O
p73	B-GENE

is	O

factors	O

%	O
in	O
the	O

,	O
p63	B-GENE
and	O

should	O
have	O

gene	O

.	O

can	O

-	O
regulated	O
genes	O
and	O

PURPOSE	O
:	O
We	O
did	O
a	O

based	O

of	O
children	O

-	O
risk	O
neuroblastoma	O
to	O

their	O
survival	O
and	O
look	O
for	O
factors	O
that	O
had	O

on	O

.	O
METHODS	O
:	O
We	O
carried	O
out	O
a	O
retrospective	O
cohort	O
study	O
of	O
patients	O
diagnosed	O
in	O
Ontario	O
from	O
1989	O
to	O
1995	O
.	O
162	O
cases	O
of	O

were	O

in	O
the	O
province	O
with	O
70	O
(	O
43	O
%	O
)	O
considered	O
high	O
-	O
risk	O
:	O

older	O
than	O
one	O

of	O

15	O

classified	O

International	O
Neuroblastoma	O

(	O

)	O

3	O
,	O
and	O
55	O

.	O

:	O

did	O
significantly	O

than	O

of	O
67.7	O
%	O

22.7	O
%	O
respectively	O
(	O
P	O
=	O
0.015	O
)	O
.	O

stage	O

at	O

to	O

.	O

,	O

oxidase	I-GENE

100	O

.	O

Human	O

neuroblastoma	O
cells	O
(	O
SH	O
-	O
SY5Y	O
)	O
have	O
been	O
widely	O
used	O
in	O
different	O

investigations	O
.	O
Quite	O
often	O

are	O
induced	O
to	O
differentiation	O

various	O

(	O

by	O
3	O

(	O

,	O

2yl	O

treated	O

more	O

.	O

of	O

-	I-GENE
2	I-GENE

gene	O

and	O

prepro-NPY	B-GENE
gene	O
.	O
Rat	O
prepro-NPY	B-GENE
(	O
98	O
amino	O
acid	O
residues	O
)	O
contains	O
a	O
36-residue	O
NPY	B-GENE
sequence	O
,	O
followed	O
by	O
a	O
proteolysis/amidation	O
site	O
Gly-Lys-Arg	O
,	O
followed	O
by	O
a	O
30-residue	O
COOH-terminal	O
sequence	O
.	O
The	O
strong	O
evolutionary	O
conservation	O
of	O
rat	O
and	O
human	O
sequences	O
of	O
NPY	B-GENE
(	O
100%	O
)	O
and	O
COOH-terminal	O
peptide	O
(	O
93%	O
)	O
suggests	O
that	O
both	O
peptides	O
have	O
important	O
biological	O
functions	O
.	O
In	O
the	O
rat	O
central	O
nervous	O
system	O
,	O
prepro-NPY	B-GENE
mRNA	O
(	O
800	O
bases	O
)	O
is	O
most	O
abundant	O
in	O
the	O
striatum	O
and	O
cortex	O
and	O

abundant	O
in	O
the	O

hypothalamus	O
,	O
and	O
spinal	O
cord	O
.	O

rat	O

,	O
spleen	O
,	O
heart	O
,	O
and	O
lung	O
have	O
significant	O
levels	O
of	O
prepro-NPY	B-GENE
mRNA	O
.	O

of	O
the	O
prepro-NPY	B-GENE
mRNA	O
abundance	O
was	O
studied	O
in	O
several	O
rodent	O
neural	O
cell	O
lines	O
.	O

rat	O

and	O
N18TG-2	O
mouse	O
neuroblastoma	O
cells	O
possess	O
low	O

mRNA	O
,	O
while	O

hybrid	O
cells	O
possess	O
high	O
levels	O
.	O

of	O

3-10-fold	O
,	O

.	O

.	O
Alpha-synuclein	B-GENE
up-regulates	O
expression	O
of	O
caveolin-1	B-GENE
and	O
down-regulates	O

activity	O
in	O
B103	O
neuroblastoma	O
cells	O
:	O
role	O
in	O
the	O
pathogenesis	O
of	O
Parkinson's	O
disease	O
.	O
Hashimoto	O
M	O
,	O
Takenouchi	O
T	O
,	O
Rockenstein	O
E	O
,	O
Masliah	O
E	O
.	O
Department	O
of	O
Neuroscience	O
,	O
University	O
of	O
California	O
at	O
San	O
Diego	O
,	O
La	O
Jolla	O
,	O
California	O
92093-0624	O
,	O
USA	O
.	O
alpha-Synuclein	B-GENE
accumulation	O
plays	O
an	O
important	O
role	O
in	O
the	O
pathogenesis	O
of	O
Lewy	O
body	O
disease	O
(	O
LBD	O
)	O
and	O
Parkinson's	O
disease	O
(	O
PD	O
)	O
.	O
Although	O
the	O
mechanisms	O
are	O
not	O
yet	O
clear	O
,	O
it	O
is	O
possible	O
that	O
dysregulation	O
of	O
the	O
extracellular	B-GENE
signal-regulated	I-GENE
kinase	I-GENE
(	O
ERK	B-GENE
)	O
might	O
play	O
a	O
role	O
.	O
As	O
caveolins	B-GENE
form	O
scaffolds	O
onto	O
which	O
signaling	O
molecules	O
such	O
as	O
ERK	B-GENE
can	O
assemble	O
,	O
we	O
propose	O
that	O
signaling	O
alterations	O
associated	O
with	O
alpha-synuclein	B-GENE
accumulation	O
and	O
neurodegeneration	O
,	O
might	O
be	O
mediated	O
via	O
caveolae	O
.	O
Therefore	O
,	O
the	O
objective	O
of	O
the	O
present	O
study	O
was	O
to	O
investigate	O
the	O
potential	O
contribution	O
of	O
alterations	O
in	O
the	O
caveolar	O
system	O
in	O
mediating	O
alpha-synuclein	B-GENE
effects	O
on	O
the	O
ERK	B-GENE
signaling	O
pathway	O
.	O
For	O
this	O
,	O
synuclein	B-GENE
-	O
transfected	O
B103	O
neuroblastoma	O
cells	O
were	O
used	O
as	O
a	O
model	O
system	O
.	O
In	O
this	O
cell	O
line	O
,	O
caveolin-1	B-GENE
expression	O
was	O
up-regulated	O
,	O
whereas	O
,	O
ERK	B-GENE
was	O
down-regulated	O
.	O
ERK	B-GENE
was	O
weakly	O
but	O
consistently	O
co-immunoprecipitated	O
with	O
alpha-synuclein	B-GENE
but	O
caveolin-1	B-GENE
did	O
not	O
co-immunoprecipitate	O
with	O
alpha-synuclein	B-GENE
.	O
Moreover	O
,	O
treatment	O
of	O
alpha-synuclein	B-GENE
-	O
overexpressing	O
cells	O
with	O
caveolin-1	B-GENE
antisense	O
oligonucleotides	O
resulted	O
in	O
stimulation	O
of	O
ERK	B-GENE
activity	O
,	O
with	O
amelioration	O
of	O
the	O
neuritic	O
alterations	O
.	O
Transduction	O
of	O
alpha-synuclein	B-GENE
-overexpressing	O
cells	O
,	O
with	O
an	O
adenoviral	O
vector	O
directing	O
the	O
expression	O
of	O
ERK	B-GENE
,	O
resulted	O
in	O
suppression	O
of	O
caveolin-1	B-GENE
expression	O
and	O
re-establishment	O
of	O
the	O
normal	O
patterns	O
of	O
neurite	O
outgrowth	O
.	O
These	O
results	O
suggest	O
that	O
alpha-synuclein	B-GENE
may	O
also	O
interfere	O
with	O
ERK	B-GENE
signaling	O
by	O
dysregulating	O
caveolin-1	B-GENE
expression	O
.	O
Thus	O
,	O
the	O
caveolin-1	B-GENE
/	O
ERK	B-GENE
pathway	O
could	O
be	O
a	O

neurodegenerative	O
disorders	O

PAINT	O
:	O
a	O

,	O

We	O
have	O
developed	O
a	O
bioinformatics	O
tool	O
named	O
PAINT	O
that	O
automates	O
the	O
promoter	O
analysis	O
of	O
a	O
given	O
set	O
of	O
genes	O
for	O
the	O
presence	O
of	O
transcription	O
factor	O
binding	O
sites	O
.	O
Based	O
on	O
coincidence	O
of	O
regulatory	O
sites	O
,	O
this	O
tool	O
produces	O
an	O
interaction	O
matrix	O
that	O
represents	O
a	O
candidate	O
transcriptional	O
regulatory	O
network	O
.	O
This	O
tool	O
currently	O
consists	O
of	O
(	O
1	O
)	O
a	O
database	O
of	O
promoter	O
sequences	O
of	O
known	O
or	O
predicted	O
genes	O
in	O
the	O
Ensembl	O
annotated	O
mouse	O
genome	O
database	O
,	O
(	O
2	O
)	O
various	O
modules	O
that	O
can	O
retrieve	O
and	O
process	O
the	O
promoter	O
sequences	O
for	O
binding	O
sites	O
of	O
known	O
transcription	O
factors	O
,	O
and	O
(	O
3	O
)	O
modules	O
for	O
visualization	O
and	O
analysis	O
of	O
the	O
resulting	O
set	O
of	O
candidate	O
network	O
connections	O
.	O
This	O
information	O
provides	O
a	O
substantially	O
pruned	O
list	O
of	O
genes	O
and	O
transcription	O
factors	O
that	O
can	O
be	O
examined	O
in	O
detail	O
in	O
further	O
experimental	O
studies	O
on	O
gene	O
regulation	O
.	O
Also	O
,	O
the	O
candidate	O
network	O
can	O
be	O
incorporated	O
into	O
network	O
identification	O
methods	O
in	O
the	O
form	O
of	O
constraints	O
on	O
feasible	O
structures	O
in	O
order	O
to	O
render	O
the	O
algorithms	O
tractable	O
for	O
large	O
-	O
scale	O
systems	O
.	O
The	O
tool	O
can	O
also	O
produce	O
output	O
in	O
various	O

for	O
use	O
in	O

.	O

that	O

on	O

that	O

phase	O
.	O

cycle	O
data	O

of	O
cyclin	B-GENE
-	I-GENE
dependent	I-GENE

inhibitors	O
p21WAF	B-GENE
and	O

,	O
and	O

.	O

of	O

and	O

decreased	O
upon	O

.	O

.	O

inhibition	O

cells	O
were	O

.	O

data	O

that	O

of	O
cell	O

.	O

.	O

motility	O
.	O

caused	O
motile	O
structures	O

freeze	O
and	O
to	O
retract	O
permanently	O

while	O

of	O

were	O

.	O

specifically	O
actin	B-GENE
-	O
containing	O
motile	O
structures	O
which	O
froze	O
and	O
retracted	O
temporarily	O
.	O

calcium	O
injections	O

a	O

site	O
of	O
injection	O
in	O
all	O
cells	O
.	O

.	O

polyphosphates	O
IP3(1,4,5)	O
and	O

did	O

that	O

.	O

that	O

.	O
